title: Why are private equity firms betting big on HR tech in Japan?
summary:
- Private equity (PE) activity in Japan is up 40.8% year over year in 2024.
- Many HR tech firms have emerged, but late-stage capital remains limited.
- Carlyle Group acquired Kaonavi for US$325 million at a 120% premium.
- Factors driving PE interest include low interest rates and a focus on governance.
- Japan's HR tech sector was valued at approximately US$2 billion in 2024, expected to grow to US$3.9 billion by 2033.

sources.title: Why are private equity firms betting big on HR tech in Japan?

title: Chinese EV maker Zeekr enters South Korean market
summary:
- Zeekr Group is entering the South Korean market as announced in court documents on March 23.
- The company established an office named Zeekr Intelligent Technology Korea in late February.
- This follows the earlier entry of another Chinese EV maker, BYD, into South Korea's passenger car market in 2023.

title: Ant Group upgrades AI for healthcare services
summary:
- Ant Group updates its AI solutions to enhance healthcare services in China.
- New tools introduced for hospitals, doctors, and individual users.
- Seven hospitals in cities like Beijing, Shanghai, Hangzhou, and Ningbo have adopted the new AI solutions.
- The healthcare large model is integrated into “All-in-One Large Model Machines for Healthcare.”
- Technology includes DeepSeek R1/V3, Alibaba’s Qwen, and Ant Group’s BaiLing.
- AI models can be deployed securely on-site to improve patient care and administrative efficiency.

title: GoTo, Google Maps partner to improve Gojek navigation
summary:
• PT GoTo Gojek Tokopedia Tbk (GoTo Group) announced a collaboration with Google Maps to enhance Gojek navigation.
• The partnership aims to optimize route navigation, reduce delivery times, and improve user and driver-partner experiences.
• Google will help GoFood merchants onboard to Google Business Profiles for better visibility and address listings.

title: S Korean civic group sues Apple over iPhone 16 AI claims
summary:
- Seoul YMCA has filed a complaint with the Fair Trade Commission (FTC) against Apple for misleading advertising regarding the iPhone 16’s AI feature.
- The complaint states that Apple promised AI-powered Siri for iOS 18, which was not included in the iPhone 16 released in September.
- The expected incorporation of the feature is now set for a future update.
- It is alleged that Apple removed related advertisements from YouTube, indicating they were aware of the delay.

sources.title: S Korean civic group sues Apple over iPhone 16 AI claims

title: Apple Watch May Introduce Built-In Cameras for Advanced AI Features
summary:
- Apple plans to release AI wearables with built-in cameras by 2027.
- Camera placement will differ: embedded in the display for standard models and on the side for Apple Watch Ultra.
- New 'Visual Intelligence' features will allow users to recognize and gather information about the outside world, similar to iPhone 16 functionalities.
- Development of these capabilities is part of Apple's broader strategy in AI, with enhancements expected by 2027.
- Integration of cameras is also being considered for AirPods and AR glasses.
- Mike Rockwell leads the project for AI improvements in wearables and visionOS software.

- Users confirm availability of live video analysis and screen-reading capabilities.
- This launch strengthens Google's position against Amazon Alexa and Apple Siri in the AI assistant market.
- The features include on-screen content interpretation and live camera feed analysis specifically for Gemini Advanced Subscribers.
- Demonstrations featured functionalities like screen-reading on Xiaomi devices and paint color selection tools.
- The rollout comes in response to competitive updates from other major AI assistants.

- The stock is still down 7% for the year, reflecting concerns about growth outlook and disappointing revenue guidance issued on Jan. 30.

title: X communications chief resigns
summary:

- His departure follows other exits from X’s communications team, including Nick Pickles in September 2024 and Joe Benarroch in June 2024.

title: JD.com food delivery hits 1m daily orders in 40 days
summary:
- JD Takeaway surpassed 1 million daily orders within 40 days of launch as of March 24.
- The service operates in 142 cities in China, featuring meals from over 450,000 restaurants.
- JD.com's zero-commission policy for merchants is credited as a significant growth factor.
- Restaurants joining before May 1, 2025, can benefit from a year without commission fees.
- JD is offering meal-subsidy draws in its app to attract users, with discounts up to 20 yuan (US$2.80) for JD Plus members and students.

summary:

- The funding will be used to expand product offerings and support micro-businesses across the Kingdom.
- Plans include enhancing a data-driven lending platform and forming partnerships in sectors like food and beverage, ecommerce, and retail.
- US$2.7 million will be allocated for debt financing to build the loan portfolio.

sources.title: Saudi fintech firm Nayla Finance raises $4m seed funding

summary:
- The Bot Company, founded by Kyle Vogt, raised $150 million in a funding round led by Greenoaks.
- The startup aims to produce a robot focused on household chores and was launched in May 2024 with an initial $150 million.
- This funding comes less than a year after Vogt resigned as CEO of Cruise following a significant incident involving a Cruise vehicle.

summary:
- Barack Obama has joined Bluesky, a social network alternative to X (formerly Twitter).

- Obama celebrated the 15th anniversary of the Affordable Care Act in his initial posts.
- He has a significant following on platforms like X (130.6 million followers) and Facebook (55 million followers).

title: Comparative Review of Simba Hybrid Pro and Otty Original Hybrid Mattresses
summary:
- The Otty Original Hybrid mattress combines pocket springs and memory foam, priced under £680 for a double.
- It has high comfort ratings, excellent sleep quality, a 100-night trial, and a 10-year warranty.
- The mattress is rated medium firm, providing good support and is environmentally safe.
- The Simba Hybrid Pro mattress was tested for three months, initially rated highly but later deemed less favorable than Otty.
- It features a 200-night trial and is priced at £1,149 for a double, with an eight-layer construction and up to 4,800 springs.
- The Simba mattress has a firmness rating of 7/10 and good motion isolation for couples, but is heavy to move.

title: Could you walk across the UK in a perfectly straight line? Inside YouTube’s strangest challenge
summary:
- The article discusses a YouTube challenge called 'straight line missioning', initiated by Tom Davies (GeoWizard).
- This challenge involves walking across landscapes in a straight line, overcoming various natural obstacles.
- Video content features participants facing challenges like fast-flowing rivers and angry landowners.
- The phenomenon has spread, with many creators attempting their own versions of the challenge.
- While often seen as pointless, it also fosters connections among friends and families.
- The activity raises questions about land ownership and private property laws in the UK.

title: Why Balatro’s developer stays anonymous
summary:

- Playstack's team accepts awards on LocalThunk's behalf to allow him the freedom to work privately.

- LocalThunk prefers to remain out of the spotlight and communicates efficiently with his team about his projects.

title: Prosecutors told to do more to strip ‘revenge porn’ abusers of victim images
summary:
- The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is updating guidance on revenge porn crimes to prevent perpetrators from retaining explicit images of victims.
- An analysis showed only 3 out of 98 cases resulted in deprivation orders for offenders to delete illicit content, leaving victims at risk of image re-sharing.
- The new guidance urges prosecutors to request deprivation orders more frequently, aiming to improve case strategies and ensure offenders lose their devices post-conviction.

title: Is it safe to travel with your phone right now?
summary:
- Recent searches by airport Customs and Border Protection (CBP) have led to public concern, with travelers being denied entry based on phone content.  
- Notable incidents include a doctor deported for holding sympathetic content regarding Hezbollah and a French scientist denied entry for criticizing the Trump administration.  
- CBP device searches are rare, accounting for less than 0.01% of travelers in the 2024 fiscal year, but are increasing compared to previous years.  
- The Supreme Court allows warrantless searches at borders, complicating traveler rights regarding digital privacy, which differ based on immigration status.  
- Travelers should minimize data on devices and consider encryption, disabling biometric logins, and utilizing cloud backups for sensitive information to protect against searches.

sources.title: Is it safe to travel with your phone right now?

title: Tech Companies Promote Healthier Social Media Habits for Kids
summary:
- An online campaign [Smartphone Free Childhood](https://www.theguardian.com/society/2025/mar/13/campaign-to-bar-under-14s-from-having-smartphones-signed-by-100000-parents) has reached 100,000 signatures to restrict smartphone ownership for kids under 14.
- Aims to delay smartphone access until after year 9 and restrict social media use until age 16.
- Notable signatures: Surrey (6,370), St Albans targeting smartphone-free status.
- Supported by celebrities like Paloma Faith and Benedict Cumberbatch.
- Ofcom: 89% of 12-year-olds own smartphones; half of kids under 13 use social media.
- Experts advise against total bans; recommend enhancing social media practices.
- Developer Rhys Kentish created [Touch Grass](https://apps.apple.com/gb/app/touch-grass-reduce-screentime/id6739589530?ign-itscg=30200&ign-itsct=apps_box_badge&mttnsubad=6739589530), an app that locks apps until users photograph real grass, launched March 17, 2025, with 50,000 downloads.
- Smartphone usage contributes to doomscrolling, negatively affecting mental health.
- Suggested methods to reduce usage include deleting distracting apps and using screen time controls.
- Global concerns about social media's impact on children's well-being increasing; Australia has prohibited under-16s from using social media.
- Companies like Yoto, Life360, and Yondr promote healthier social media engagement for kids.

sources.title: Campaign to bar under-14s from having smartphones signed by 100,000 parents
Young people: what rules around smartphone use should be put in place for children?
Social media addicts: Here are tips to stop wasting time on apps
This app limits your screen time by making you literally touch grass
How to stop doomscrolling
These tech companies are building healthier social media habits for kids

title: Grab's Acquisition of Nham24 Marks a Milestone for Cambodia's Tech Scene
summary:
- Grab acquired local on-demand startup Nham24 in December 2024, marking an important milestone for Cambodia's tech scene.
- CEO of Aquarii BD Cambodia, Michael Tan, noted that the acquisition was long overdue, as he suggested Grab invest in Nham24 back in 2017.
- The delay in the deal reflects the underestimation of Cambodia's tech ecosystem by regional and global players.
- Cambodia’s low market saturation may offer fertile ground for startups seeking first-mover advantages despite the country's lagging macroeconomic environment.
- Grab's acquisition enhances its presence in Cambodia's tech scene and signals its intent to dominate the market, which has significant growth potential.
- The deal underscores the shift in focus towards Cambodia as an emerging market within Southeast Asia's digital economy.

sources.title: Cambodia eyes the big leagues after Grab bets on local firm
Grab deal shines light on Cambodia

title: Adolescents and the Dangers of Smartphones: A Call for Action
summary:
- Jack Thorne proposes banning smartphones for under-16s in the UK, likening them to cigarettes.
- Highlights the dangers of social media algorithms leading teens to harmful content.
- Advocates for government action similar to regulations in France, Norway, and Australia.
- The Netflix show *Adolescence*, co-written by Thorne, addresses online misogyny and incel culture.
- The series follows a 13-year-old boy navigating dangerous online spaces and perceptions of emojis.
- Academics warn of rising anti-feminist sentiments fueled by social media and incel culture.
- The Online Safety Act in the UK aims to regulate harmful content but struggles with incel-related emojis.
- The series discusses influencers like Andrew Tate radicalizing boys online.
- Political discussions around addressing misogyny and online influence on boys are ongoing.
- Suggests that reducing smartphone use may be more effective than youth program investments.
- A survey indicates 40% of teens spending six hours or more online daily.
- Growing debates on restricting teen access to social media, echoed by other countries.

sources.title: Ban smartphones for UK under-16s, urges Adolescence writer
Adolescence reveals a terrifying truth: smartphones are poison for boys’ minds

title: Cloudflare launches new tool to block AI web scrapers
summary:
- Cloudflare has launched AI Labyrinth, a new tool for blocking web-crawling bots that scrape data for AI training without permission.
- Unlike traditional methods, AI Labyrinth employs AI-generated decoy pages to mislead these bots.
- The tool functions as a “next-generation honeypot,” trapping AI crawlers in loops of fake content.
- Website administrators can enable AI Labyrinth from the Bot Management section of their Cloudflare dashboard.
- Future developments will include creating interconnected networks of fake URLs to enhance the tool's effectiveness against advanced bot strategies.

sources.title: Cloudflare launches new tool to block AI web scrapers

title: Indian tech incubator invests $3.6m seed capital in 136 startups
summary:
- Software Technology Parks of India (STPI) invested 30.87 crore rupee (US$3.59 million) in 136 startups as of Mar. 21.
- STPI also provided 3.57 crore rupee (US$415,162) in stipends to 359 startups.
- 134 startups backed by STPI have secured 286 crore rupee (US$33.26 million) in external funding.
- Women entrepreneurs lead 44% of STPI’s portfolio startups, many from Tier-II and Tier-III cities.
- STPI operates 13+ centers of excellence focusing on healthtech, IoT, and agritech.
- Aligns with commerce minister Piyush Goyal’s goal of creating 5,000 unicorns in India.

- Astroscale offers on-orbit servicing solutions, while Digantara focuses on space debris detection and Bellatrix develops eco-friendly satellite propulsion systems.

- Norges Bank invests $8.11 million in Nazara Technologies, acquiring 719,000 shares at ₹969.65 each.
- This is Norges Bank's first investment in Nazara.
- Nazara's stock performance has been mixed since its debut in March 2021, currently down 4.5% year-to-date but up 5.01% over the last month.

title: US watchdog investigates nine Chinese firms for rule evasion
summary:
- The FCC is investigating nine Chinese companies for potentially evading US restrictions, including Huawei and ZTE.
- Other firms under investigation are China Mobile, China Telecom, Hytera Communications, Dahua Technology, Pacifica Networks/ComNet, and China Unicom (Americas).
- FCC Chair Brendan Carr noted that these companies may exploit regulatory loopholes to operate in the US.
- The investigation includes Letters of Inquiry and at least one subpoena to gather detailed activities of these firms.
- This action is part of a broader effort to secure US communications, following previous bans on Chinese firms providing telecom services due to security risks.

title: 7-Eleven operator reportedly selling US outlets
summary:
- Japanese retailer Seven & i Holdings is considering selling its US 7-Eleven outlets due to antitrust concerns related to takeover talks with Alimentation Couche-Tard.
- The company clarified that this consideration does not imply acceptance of Couche-Tard’s US$47 billion acquisition proposal.
- Seven & i stated that Couche-Tard must divest its US stores for the deal to move forward, and both companies have signed a confidentiality agreement to discuss potential buyers.

sources.title: 7-Eleven operator reportedly selling US outlets

title: Italian newspaper launches AI-only journalism experiment
summary:
- Italian newspaper Il Foglio launched an experimental project called Foglio AI, using AI to write all content.
- The project is among the first of its kind for a national newspaper, exploring AI's potential in journalism.
- Foglio AI produces clear content but faces criticism for lacking investigative depth and emotional nuance.
- AI-generated articles are readable but struggle with subjective interpretations and direct source interactions.
- The initiative is intended to understand AI's capabilities, not to replace human journalists.

sources.title: Italian newspaper launches AI-only journalism experiment

title: Perplexity plans US oversight for TikTok’s algorithm
summary:
- Perplexity AI proposes to restructure TikTok’s algorithm under US oversight to enhance transparency and user experience.
- The plan utilizes Nvidia Dynamo technology to improve TikTok's recommendation system, focusing on scalability and compliance with US privacy regulations.
- Features include context-driven capabilities for real-time information verification using AI and community input, shifting focus from engagement metrics to informational value.

sources.title: Perplexity plans US oversight for TikTok’s algorithm

title: Ex-US prosecutor’s VC firm raises $1b for crypto investments
summary:

- Haun Ventures has invested in crypto infrastructure and stablecoin projects, backing companies like Bridge and BVNK.

- Adaptations to the industry include hiring Anchorage cofounder Diogo Mónico as a general partner.

title: Jonah Peretti helped shaped digital media — can he do it again?
summary:
- Jonah Peretti, as the CEO of [BuzzFeed](https://www.buzzfeed.com/), has been a significant figure in digital media for nearly two decades.
- BuzzFeed has transformed from a startup to a multimedia powerhouse, but faces questions about its long-term strategy and stability.
- Peretti emphasizes his adaptability in a constantly changing media landscape, focusing on AI-driven content and projects like BF Island.
- BuzzFeed sold assets, including Complex Networks and First We Feast, reflecting challenges in maintaining its business model.
- The company's stock has dropped significantly, from an initial price of $10 to $2.20 per share, raising concerns among shareholders.
- Peretti argues that experimentation and innovation are crucial in navigating the evolving media market, despite the risks involved.

sources.title: Jonah Peretti helped shaped digital media — can he do it again?

- 01.AI, founded in mid-2023, initially focused on large language models but is now transitioning to a solutions provider.
- The company can customize DeepSeek’s models for specific business needs, differentiating it from competitors.
- DeepSeek's open-source model is gaining popularity among Chinese vendors, creating growth opportunities for 01.AI.

summary:
- Fore Coffee aims to raise 379.8 billion rupiah (US$24 million) through its IPO on April 11.

- 76% of IPO proceeds will be allocated to expanding its outlet network across Indonesia, targeting up to 600 locations in four years.
- The book-building period took place from March 19 to 21, with public offering from March 26 to April 9.
- Fore Coffee will be the first coffee chain in Indonesia to go public, competing with established brands like Kopi Kenangan and Toko Kopi Tuku.

title: PayU acquires 43.5% stake in Indian fintech firm Mindgate
summary:
- PayU, the fintech arm of Prosus, acquires a 43.5% stake in Mindgate Solutions, maintaining majority ownership for its founders.
- Mindgate specializes in real-time payments technology and supports India’s Unified Payments Interface (UPI), processing over 8 billion transactions monthly for banks.
- The investment enhances PayU’s position in India's digital payments sector and accelerates global expansion, leveraging Mindgate’s expertise as UPI transactions are projected to reach 100 billion monthly by 2030.
- Mindgate operates in regions including MENA, ASEAN, Europe, and the US, aiming to innovate real-time digital payments in collaboration with PayU.

- Setup involves Bluetooth and Wi-Fi, and the camera is expected to launch in fall 2025, but details on pricing and specs are still unavailable.

title: Charlie Javice trial becomes a master class in hubris for both sides
summary:
- Charlie Javice's fraud trial focuses on her allegedly deceiving JPMorgan Chase into acquiring her startup Frank for $175 million, despite having only 300,000 customers.
- Former Frank engineer Patrick Vovor testified that Javice requested him to create fake user data but refused, prompting her to seek help from a math professor instead.
- The trial reveals that JPMorgan did not thoroughly vet Frank's user base, highlighting a lack of due diligence in the deal.

sources.title: Charlie Javice trial becomes a master class in hubris for both sides

title: Cloudflare Uses AI Labyrinth to Combat Web-Scraping Bots
summary:
- Cloudflare has launched a new feature called [AI Labyrinth](https://blog.cloudflare.com/ai-labyrinth/) to combat unauthorized AI data scraping.
- The tool serves fake AI-generated content to bots, wasting their resources rather than blocking them.
- This approach is a shift from traditional strategies and aims to protect websites by enticing crawlers into a maze of irrelevant pages.
- The AI-generated content is based on real scientific facts to avoid spreading misinformation.
- AI Labyrinth operates as a next-generation honeypot, designed to deceive modern bots more effectively by embedding false links that are invisible to human visitors.
- Cloudflare has launched AI Labyrinth, a tool to combat web-scraping bots.
- The tool lures harmful crawlers into decoy pages to waste their resources.
- It identifies and fingerprints malicious bots to improve defenses.
- Website administrators can opt in via the Cloudflare dashboard.
- AI Labyrinth aims to develop networks of linked URLs to further trap bots.

sources.title: Cloudflare turns AI against itself with endless maze of irrelevant facts
Cloudflare is luring web-scraping bots into an ‘AI Labyrinth’

title: Reid Hoffman: ‘Start using AI deeply. It is a huge intelligence amplifier’
summary:
- Reid Hoffman, co-founder of LinkedIn, discusses the potential of AI in his new book 'Superagency'.
- He emphasizes AI's role as an 'intelligence amplifier' that can enhance human agency and empowerment.
- Hoffman asserts the AI revolution could bring about a 'cognitive Industrial Revolution', despite concerns about negative impacts on jobs.
- He differentiates beneficial AI tools like chatbots from harmful technologies such as facial recognition and surveillance.
- He encourages embracing AI for job transformation rather than fearing obsolescence, promoting a mindset of adaptation.

title: Copilot exposes private GitHub pages, some removed by Microsoft
summary:
- Microsoft’s Copilot AI assistant exposed over 20,000 private GitHub repositories from major companies including Google, Intel, and Microsoft itself.
- These repositories were previously public but switched to private due to sensitive information being present.
- AI security firm Lasso discovered the issue in late 2024, finding Copilot continued to access and expose these private repositories.
- The problem was traced to Bing's cache, which did not remove entries when repositories changed from public to private.
- Microsoft has made changes following Lasso's report in November, but a repository related to a lawsuit against Microsoft remained exposed until removed.

sources.title: Copilot exposes private GitHub pages, some removed by Microsoft

title: As the Kernel Turns: Rust in Linux saga reaches the “Linus in all-caps” phase
summary:
- Rust, a memory-safe programming language, is making its way into the Linux kernel amidst ongoing debates.
- Linus Torvalds approved Rust code support in the kernel in October 2022, but progress has faced frustrations and stalls.
- Hector Martin resigned from the Linux maintainers list, citing burnout and roadblocks in implementing Rust for efficient driver work.

sources.title: As the Kernel Turns: Rust in Linux saga reaches the “Linus in all-caps” phase

title: Anthropic Introduces Web Search in Claude Chatbot as Part of AI Strategy
summary:
- Anthropic is focusing on advanced AI models and vertical experiences rather than mass-market adoption.
- Claude Code reached 100,000 users in its first week, indicating strong interest in targeted applications.
- Plans for more AI agents and developing smaller, cheaper models for developers are in place.
- Web search capabilities have been added to the Claude chatbot, currently in 'feature preview' for U.S. users of the Claude 3.7 Sonnet model.
- Claude autonomously decides if web search enhances its responses, contrasting with OpenAI's manual search selection.

sources.title: Anthropic’s plan to win the AI race
Anthropic is adding web search to its Claude chatbot in a very smart way

title: Meta has revenue sharing agreements with Llama AI model hosts, filing reveals
summary:
- Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg stated that selling access to Llama AI models is not their primary business model, but they do have revenue-sharing agreements.
- A court filing reveals Meta shares a portion of revenue from companies hosting Llama models, although specific hosts are not detailed.
- Notable Llama host partners include AWS, Nvidia, Databricks, Groq, Dell, Azure, Google Cloud, and Snowflake.
- Developers can run Llama models independently but often utilize hosts for additional services.
- Zuckerberg mentioned potential monetization strategies for Llama, including licensing and ads.
- The revenue generation is significant due to ongoing copyright litigation regarding alleged training on pirated materials.
- Meta plans large capital expenditures for AI, estimating $60 billion-$80 billion in 2025 primarily for data centers and AI development.

sources.title: Meta has revenue sharing agreements with Llama AI model hosts, filing reveals

title: The best MagSafe and Qi2 chargers
summary:
- Wireless charging offers convenience though it's generally less efficient than wired charging.
- Qi2 chargers are recommended for iPhones from the 12 series onwards, providing up to 15W charging, equivalent to MagSafe except for iPhone 16 which can charge at 25W.
- Qi2 is an open standard and typically less expensive than MagSafe options, with a wider range of chargers available.
- Samsung Galaxy S25 devices are Qi2 ready, requiring a special magnetic case to utilize the full charging speed on Qi2 chargers.
- Qi2 certification ensures proper charging performance and magnet alignment, replacing older MagSafe-compatible chargers.

sources.title: The best MagSafe and Qi2 chargers

title: Drama over quantum computing’s future heats up
summary:
- On March 18, Chetan Nayak of Microsoft presented quantum chip data at the American Physical Society summit amid ongoing skepticism.
- Microsoft claims a new topological qubit is less prone to errors, but researchers are doubtful of the evidence.
- Controversy stems from Microsoft's past retraction of similar claims and concerns over the timeline for useful quantum computing applications.
- Experts predict a decade before quantum computers become useful for practical applications, with current research focusing on reducing errors and scaling up qubits.
- Governments and private sectors are investing heavily in quantum technology, but overhype risks a potential 'quantum winter' due to inflated expectations.

sources.title: Drama over quantum computing’s future heats up

title: How BYD plans to make EV charging as fast as filling a gas tank
summary:
- BYD's Han L sedan can add up to 248 miles of range in just five minutes of charging.
- The vehicle features an 83.2 kWh lithium-iron-phosphate battery operating at approximately 945 volts.
- BYD's dual gun charging system allows the car to charge at 1 megawatt, utilizing two ports simultaneously.
- Realistic range from a five-minute charge is approximately 160 miles due to optimistic testing cycles.
- BYD plans to install over 4,000 charging stations across China, with significant upgrades needed for existing infrastructure.
- Current U.S. market challenges may delay BYD's entry due to tariffs on Chinese EVs.

sources.title: How BYD plans to make EV charging as fast as filling a gas tank

title: Watch this ultra-detailed animation of the seafloor
summary:
- NASA released a video showing a detailed new map of the ocean floor enabled by the SWOT satellite.
- The SWOT satellite, launched in 2022, has provided higher-resolution data compared to previous mapping technologies.
- Maps created from SWOT data enhance submarine navigation and assist in laying and repairing underwater communication cables.
- The gravity-based mapping technique reveals features like abyssal hills and seamounts, which cover about 70% of the ocean floor.
- While sonar ships have mapped only about a quarter of the ocean floor, SWOT dramatically improves the process.
- The primary mission of SWOT is to measure the height of water over oceans, rivers, and lakes, aimed at a comprehensive survey of Earth's surface water.

sources.title: Watch this ultra-detailed animation of the seafloor

title: Notorious crooks broke into a company network in 48 minutes. Here’s how.
summary:
- In December, a manufacturing company faced a surge of phishing messages, leading to a network breach within 48 minutes.
- Attackers, likely part of the Black Basta ransomware group, used a Microsoft Teams decoy to gain initial access through employee remote desktop sharing.
- ReliaQuest noted a 22% reduction in breakout time in 2024 compared to the previous year, emphasizing the importance of swift threat containment to prevent data loss and reputational damage.
- The attackers manipulated various tools, including DLL sideloading and PowerShell, showcasing sophisticated breach techniques and rapid lateral movement within the network.

sources.title: Notorious crooks broke into a company network in 48 minutes. Here’s how.

title: Valve removes video game demo suspected of being malware
summary:
- Valve removed the video game demo for Sniper: Phantom’s Resolution from its online store, Steam, after user reports of malware installation.
- The game promised realistic first-person shooter mechanics, dynamic storytelling, and high-stakes missions.
- Reports of the malware stemmed from Reddit users who analyzed the demo, leading to its removal, reminiscent of a previous incident with PirateFi in February.

sources.title: Valve removes video game demo suspected of being malware

title: Meta Faces Challenges with Ex-Employee's Memoir 'Careless People'
summary:
- Meta won a legal victory against ex-employee Sarah Wynn-Williams, author of the memoir "Careless People."
- An arbitrator ruled Wynn-Williams may have violated a non-disparagement agreement.
- Despite the ruling, the book remains a bestseller on Amazon, potentially due to the "Streisand Effect."
- Macmillan, the publisher, supports the book and criticizes Meta's attempt to silence the author.
- Wynn-Williams claims her memoir offers insights into Facebook's operations and her experiences there from 2011 to 2017.
- Meta has dismissed the memoir as a mix of outdated claims and false accusations about executives.
- Wynn-Williams filed an emergency motion to dismiss a gag order preventing her from discussing the book.
- Her book has attracted interest from Congress and governments due to claims about Meta's coordination with the Chinese Communist Party and exploitation of vulnerable teens.
- Critics challenge details in Wynn-Williams' book, alleging factual inaccuracies and exaggerations.
- Some former Facebook employees endorse the book for capturing the Silicon Valley work environment's essence.

sources.title: Meta takes aim at ex-employee’s memoir ‘Careless People’
How ‘Careless People’ is becoming a bigger problem for Meta

title: ICE is going after more international students
summary:
- Mahmoud Khalil, a graduate student at Columbia University, was detained by immigration agents for pro-Palestine protest involvement.
- DHS has arrested additional students, including Badar Khan Suri from Georgetown University, who is accused of posing a threat to US foreign policy.
- A federal judge has temporarily barred the deportation of Suri, who is being held at an ICE detention center in Louisiana.
- Claims of Suri's alleged connection to Hamas are based on family ties; his wife is a US citizen.
- Momodou Taal, a Cornell University student, has also been targeted for political activism and fears retaliation for his criticisms of US foreign policy.
- Taal's attorneys report that the DOJ intends to serve him with a Notice to Appear in immigration court.

sources.title: ICE is going after more international students

title: Anthropic’s AI Chatbot Claude Integrates Brave for Web Search Capabilities
summary:
- Anthropic launched a web search feature for its AI chatbot Claude.
- Evidence indicates that Brave Search is powering Claude's web search functionality.
- Brave previously collaborated with Mistral for chatbot search capabilities.
- Other AI companies, like OpenAI, have undisclosed partnerships for web search.
- Anthropic has not confirmed the partnership with Brave despite its inclusion in the subprocessors list.
- Users are warned about potential inaccuracies in AI-generated citations, with studies showing a 60% error rate.
- Claude outputs citations for online sources but lacks released accuracy benchmarks.

sources.title: Anthropic appears to be using Brave to power web searches for its Claude chatbot
Anthropic’s new AI search feature digs through the web for answers

title: In this horror game, the monster can see you through your webcam
summary:
- The horror game, *Eyes Never Wake*, uses a webcam to track players' movements in real time.
- Players must physically hide and stay silent to avoid being caught by an AI-driven monster.
- Available for wishlisting on Steam, the game has become viral, with a post on X gaining over 5.4 million views.
- Developers have stated that covering the webcam will inhibit movement, and no data is uploaded or stored during gameplay.
- No confirmed release date, but it is expected to launch soon on [Steam](https://store.steampowered.com/app/2526200/Eyes_Never_Wake/).

sources.title: In this horror game, the monster can see you through your webcam

title: DeepSeek: Everything You Need to Know About the AI Chatbot App
summary:
- AI models from Chinese labs like [DeepSeek](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/14/deepseek-everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-ai-chatbot-app/) censor politically sensitive topics due to a 2023 law.
- A developer found that AI responses differ by language, especially on sensitive topics.
- Alibaba's [Qwen 2.5 72B Instruct](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/20/ais-answers-on-china-differ-depending-on-the-language-analysis-finds/) was compliant in English but less so in Chinese; others like [R1 1776](https://www.perplexity.ai/fr/hub/blog/open-sourcing-r1-1776) showed significant differences.
- Discrepancies due to training data and political censorship influence on AI training.
- DeepSeek's chatbot app reached the top of Apple and Google Play charts.
- Backed by High-Flyer Capital Management, DeepSeek began in 2023 focusing on AI tools.
- Launched first AI models in November 2023, gaining recognition with next-gen models in 2024.
- Outperformed competitors while being cheaper, pushing rivals to lower prices.
- Faces challenges from U.S. export bans and Chinese regulatory scrutiny.
- Some companies, including Microsoft, incorporated DeepSeek models despite national security concerns.

sources.title: AI’s answers on China differ depending on the language, analysis finds
DeepSeek: Everything you need to know about the AI chatbot app

title: Samsung admits its bad software update bricked a lot of soundbars
summary:
- Samsung confirmed that a software update error caused issues with certain 2024 soundbar devices.
- Affected models include flagship HW-Q990D, HW-Q800D, and HW-S801D.
- Samsung is offering free repairs for impacted units, regardless of warranty status.
- Users reported devices were unresponsive and could not be factory reset after the update.
- Physical repairs are needed, as it cannot be fixed with another software update.

sources.title: Samsung admits its bad software update bricked a lot of soundbars

title: Perplexity wants to buy TikTok and open-source its algorithm
summary:
- Perplexity proposed a bid to acquire TikTok and transform its platform.
- The bid aims to rebuild TikTok’s algorithm in the U.S. with an emphasis on transparency and open source.
- Key proposals include integrating AI tech, enhancing personalization, and adding multilingual capabilities.
- ByteDance's sale reluctance, previous legal challenges, and competitive bids from larger companies complicate the process.
- Analysts estimate TikTok’s U.S. operations value between $30-$50 billion and uncertainty exists around the seriousness of Perplexity's bid.

sources.title: Perplexity wants to buy TikTok and open-source its algorithm

title: Alexa Plus is coming to almost every Echo — but your favorite skill might not make the cut
summary: - Alexa Plus, a new AI-powered voice assistant, will be available on Echo devices in the coming weeks. - Available on Echo Show 8, 10, 15, and 21, Fire TV devices, Fire tablets, and the web, but not on older Echo devices. - Users can sign up for early access via the Alexa Plus landing page. - Free during early access; will eventually require a $19.99/month subscription or Amazon Prime. - Alexa Plus can process multiple commands and understand natural language, responding to user emotion. - Not all existing Alexa skills will be available at launch; some users may lose their favorite skills.

title: HP realizes that mandatory 15-minute support call wait times isn’t good support
summary:
- HP implemented forced 15-minute wait times for customer tech support calls in the UK, France, Germany, Ireland, and Italy.
- The intention was to encourage customers to use digital self-solve resources instead of speaking to representatives.
- The mandatory wait times have been lifted following customer feedback emphasizing the importance of timely access to live support.

summary:
- TechCrunch acquired by Regent, a private equity firm.
- Deal ensures minimal operational disruption with a move to new SoMa offices.
- Yahoo retains a small stake in TechCrunch, acknowledging its portfolio significance.
- Leadership and journalism teams remain intact, focused on original reporting.
- TechCrunch's readership has grown despite industry challenges.

- Previous ownership includes AOL and Verizon acquisitions.

summary:
- Amazon’s Big Spring Sale starts on March 25 and runs until March 31, 2025.
- Discounts available on various products including security cameras, smartwatches, and portable speakers.
- Notable early deals include:
  - [Google Pixel Tablet](https://www.amazon.com/Google-Pixel-Tablet-Extra-Long-Porcelain/dp/B0CZMFZ84J?tag=theverge02-20) for $279, featuring Tensor G2 chip and 11-inch LCD display.

title: Elon Musk is paying voters again ahead of the Wisconsin Supreme Court election
summary:
- Elon Musk's America PAC is offering $100 to registered voters who sign a petition against 'activist judges' in Wisconsin.
- This is a similar tactic to what Musk employed before the presidential election, where he promised money for petition signatures.
- The legality of this offer is debated, as it doesn't explicitly require individuals to vote.
- The Wisconsin Supreme Court election, scheduled for April 1, 2024, is critical for determining the ideological balance of the court.
- Over $76 million has been spent on this election, with Musk’s groups contributing over $14 million to support conservative candidate Brad Schimel, who is currently trailing.
- The petition process collects voter information, potentially allowing targeted campaigning in the lead-up to the election.
- Musk's interest in this election is also linked to Tesla's legal battles in Wisconsin over dealership regulations.

sources.title: Elon Musk is paying voters again ahead of the Wisconsin Supreme Court election

title: Startups Weekly: Wiz Makes Big Moves Amidst M&A Activity and Unicorn Growth in India
summary:
- Zhipu, a Chinese AI startup, raised over 1 billion yuan (US$140 million) led by government entities in Hangzhou.
- Israel's startups secured over $550 million in 13 deals in February 2025, up 85% from February 2024.
- Largest Israeli deal was $170 million from Quantum Machines, valuing it at $700 million.
- Notable funding includes $75 million for Augury and $50 million for Blockaid.
- Highlights 50 Indonesian startups with significant investor funding from Tech in Asia.
- Lists 50 Korean startups and tech companies with the highest fundraising amounts.
- Darwinbox secured US$140 million in a series E funding round co-led by Partners Group and KKR.
- Flow48 raised US$69 million in series A funding led by Breega.
- NXin received US$39.8 million in strategic funding.
- Grain locked in US$33 million in series A funding led by Bain Capital Ventures.
- Freshreview was acquired by GaragePlug; amount undisclosed.
- Funding is critical for startups and varies by stage; economic conditions affect investor sentiment.
- Delays in funding can lead to operational jeopardy, layoffs, or bankruptcy, while faster funding enhances growth and survival.
- India added 70 unicorns from 2021 to 2024, reaching a total of 105.
- 2021 and 2022 saw nearly 60% of unicorns achieved their valuation during a funding boom.
- The total capital raised by Indian startups in 2024 dropped to around US$17 billion, a threefold decrease from 2020.
- Byju's, once the most valuable startup, is facing insolvency in 2024.
- Nine new unicorns emerged in India since 2024, with notable inclusions in fintech, logistics, and biotech.
- Major investors include Peak XV, Tiger Global, Accel Partners, and Elevation Capital.
- Four startups with billion-dollar valuations went public in 2024, contrasting with Southeast Asia, where no unicorns have gone public since late 2022.
- Wiz walks away from a $23 billion offer from Google, which later agrees to acquire Wiz for a record $32 billion in cash, plus $1 billion in retention bonuses.
- SoftBank to acquire Ampere Computing for $6.5 billion in an all-cash deal.
- Next Insurance gets acquired by Munich Re for $2.6 billion.
- Nvidia reportedly acquires Gretel, a synthetic data startup, for over $320 million.
- Klarna signs as Walmart's exclusive BNPL partner after its IPO filing.
- Flexport sues former employees for allegedly stealing code to create a rival startup, Freightmate AI.
- New startup Spangle AI aims to create custom landing pages for e-commerce shoppers, launched by former Bolt CEO.
- Evroc raises $55 million for a European hyperscale cloud project.
- Graphite, an AI-powered code-review platform, secures $52 million in funding.

summary:
- Waymo has struck a deal with San Francisco Airport to map airport roadways, with future potential for robotaxi expansion.
- The agreement includes data-sharing requirements and prohibits the use of autonomous vehicles for moving commercial goods.
- Coreshell raised $24 million in funding; Einride may file for an IPO valuing at over $5 billion; Evera raised 2 million euros; Leta secured $5 million in seed funding; Seadronix received $11.3 million in Series B funding.

summary:
- Tesla CEO Elon Musk presents the Cybercab prototype, a fully driverless vehicle, in Burbank, California.
- A new vehicle, the Robovan, is introduced, designed for mass transit or cargo.
- Musk acknowledges previous delays in driverless technology development.
- Reactions to the showcase may impact Tesla's competitive edge in self-driving technology.
- The Cybercab features a sleek design and relies on wireless inductive charging.
- A surprise all-hands meeting in Texas was held to address stock declines and future plans.
- Musk promises the production of 5,000 Optimus robots this year.
- A new manufacturing process for Cybercab could allow for production of one unit in under five seconds, with an estimated price of $30,000 by 2026.

title: Anker’s small and light 45W USB-C charger is now even smaller and lighter
summary:
- Anker's new 45W Nano charger measures 1.45 inches long and weighs 52 grams.
- It is 17 grams lighter than the previous model, the Nano II 713.
- The charger is available on [Amazon](https://www.amazon.com/Anker-Nano-Charger-USB-C-Cable/dp/B0DPKRC84P??tag=theverge02-20) for $34.99, including a six-foot USB-C cable.
- Supports Samsung's Super Fast Charging, allowing the Samsung S25 Ultra to charge to 70% in 30 minutes.
- Its dimensions are 1.30 × 1.26 × 1.45 inches when including the bundled cable's weight, totaling 58 grams.

title: Fewer than 500 people are responsible for $3.2 trillion of artificial crypto trading
summary:
- Market manipulation in cryptocurrency involves fewer than 500 individuals, generating over $3.2 trillion in artificial trading.
- A study from University College London’s Honglin Fu describes the use of a tool named Perseus to track pump-and-dump schemes.
- Telegram is often used to coordinate these schemes, with Perseus identifying over 400 masterminds and 750,000 messages related to fraud.

sources.title: Fewer than 500 people are responsible for $3.2 trillion of artificial crypto trading

title: Video game music has arrived on the festival circuit – and it’s only going to get bigger
summary:
- The London Soundtrack Festival runs from March 19 to March 26, 2025, celebrating video game music alongside film and TV soundtracks.
- Tommy Pearson, the festival's founder, emphasizes the artistic importance of video game music as a separate genre.
- Key events include performances by the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra and masterclasses led by Grammy-winning composers.
- Video game soundtracks are gaining popularity with millions of daily streams on platforms like Instagram and TikTok.
- Composers such as Ludvig Forssell, Harry Gregson-Williams, and Stephanie Economou will participate in discussions and performances at the festival.
- Economou notes the prevalence of recognizable video game music in popular culture, as the gaming industry surpasses traditional media in profitability.

sources.title: Video game music has arrived on the festival circuit – and it’s only going to get bigger

title: Elon Musk's Stock Hold Reminder Amid Global Tesla Protests
summary:
- Organizers plan 500 "Tesla Takedown" protests worldwide on March 29.
- Protests target Musk's influence and government budget cuts, urging consumers to divest from Tesla.
- Peaceful demonstrations expected at all 277 Tesla U.S. showrooms and 223 globally.
- Recent vandalism against Tesla labeled as domestic terrorism by officials.
- Musk reassured employees of Tesla's future, encouraging them to hold onto stock despite 50% price drop.
- Backlash includes vandalism and arson against Tesla vehicles.
- Tesla recalled nearly 46,000 Cybertrucks due to a safety issue.
- Analyst describes situation as a global brand crisis for Tesla.
- Musk maintains that Tesla vehicles will achieve full autonomy eventually.

title: ChatGPT and Anthropic's Claude Chatbot Now Offers Web Search Capabilities
summary:
- Anthropic's AI chatbot Claude can now perform web searches, a previously unavailable feature.
- Web search is currently in preview for paid users in the U.S.; support for free users and additional countries will follow.
- Users can enable web search in their profile settings from the Claude web app, which will provide direct citations for information.
- This feature allows Claude to offer answers based on real-time insights, positioning it on par with competitors like ChatGPT, Google’s Gemini, and others.
- There are risks involved, such as the potential for hallucinations or incorrect citations from web sources, which is a common issue among chatbots.

- ChatGPT, launched by OpenAI in November 2022, has gained popularity with over [300 million weekly active users](https://www.theinformation.com/briefings/openai-surpasses-300-million-weekly-active-users).
- In 2024, OpenAI announced partnerships (e.g., with Apple for generative AI) and new releases like [GPT-4o with voice capabilities](https://techcrunch.com/2024/12/12/chatgpt-now-understands-real-time-video-seven-months-after-openai-first-demoed-it/) and the text-to-video model Sora.
- OpenAI faced legal challenges, including lawsuits and scrutiny over its transition to a for-profit structure, and internal departures of execs like [Ilya Sutskever](https://techcrunch.com/2024/05/14/ilya-sutskever-openai-co-founder-and-longtime-chief-scientist-departs/?utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=tc&utm_campaign=tc_week_in_review).
- Notable developments in 2025 include a [privacy complaint in Europe](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/19/chatgpt-hit-with-privacy-complaint-over-defamatory-hallucinations/) and upgrades to transcription and voice-generating models.
- OpenAI reported plans to [charge up to $20,000 a month](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/05/openai-reportedly-plans-to-charge-up-to-20000-a-month-for-specialized-ai-agents/?utm_campaign=tc_week_in_review&utm_medium=newsletter&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-8FzNR8H1_dsObV2gcIx4Q_s93NalU5zuUUx-jctJ62xqnRwNGxc2gr5utyX0DuL-91VpBVongHzoJ8hJ3OehgsNFdCBQ&_hsmi=350636795&utm_source=tc) for AI agents aimed at various applications.

sources.title: Anthropic adds web search to its Claude chatbot
ChatGPT: Everything you need to know about the AI-powered chatbot

title: Wayve CEO shares his key ingredients for scaling autonomous driving tech
summary:
- Wayve's CEO Alex Kendall outlines a strategy for scaling autonomous driving tech focusing on affordability and hardware flexibility.
- The company utilizes a data-driven learning approach relying on sensors without HD maps.
- Wayve has raised over $1.3 billion and is in discussions with multiple OEMs to integrate its software into various vehicle types.
- The software works with existing sensors, making it cost-effective for automotive partners.
- Wayve's AI aims to achieve Level 4 autonomy and incorporates lidar for improved performance.
- Kendall reveals GAIA-2, an advanced generative world model for training autonomous driving AI.

sources.title: Wayve CEO shares his key ingredients for scaling autonomous driving tech

title: Opening iOS is good news for smartwatches
summary:
- The European Commission has mandated Apple to open up iOS interoperability to other device manufacturers.
- This change will allow third-party smartwatches to interact with iOS notifications, enhancing user experience.
- Apple's previous restrictions limited the functionality of third-party devices compared to Apple Watches, which offered seamless integration with iOS devices.
- Critics, including Apple, argue that this move could stifle innovation by forcing the company to share features with competitors.
- Lack of recent innovation in smartwatches has contributed to stagnant market interest, leading to a desire for more creativity and options in smartwatch design.

sources.title: Opening iOS is good news for smartwatches

title: Microsoft Explores AI Training Data Credit System Amid Copyright Lawsuits Against OpenAI and Meta
summary:
- Alec Radford, ex-OpenAI researcher, subpoenaed in a copyright case against OpenAI on February 25.
- Plaintiffs include authors Paul Tremblay, Sarah Silverman, and Michael Chabon, alleging copyright infringement related to OpenAI's AI models.
- OpenAI claims its use falls under fair use; previous claims against OpenAI were dismissed, but the direct infringement claim continues.
- A federal judge allows an AI-related copyright lawsuit against Meta to proceed, dismissing part of the suit.
- Authors allege Meta used their works to train Llama AI and removed copyright info to conceal infringement.
- Meta claims its usage qualifies as fair use and challenges the authors' standing to sue.
- Judge Vince Chhabria supports the authors' claims of copyright infringement and intentional removal of copyright management information (CMI).
- Claims related to the California Comprehensive Computer Data Access and Fraud Act (CDAFA) were dismissed due to lack of sufficient allegations.
- Microsoft is launching a research project to estimate the influence of specific training examples on AI model outputs.
- The project aims to provide recognition and potential compensation for contributors of training data.
- There are ongoing legal challenges against Microsoft regarding AI training data usage, with major firms advocating for fair use in AI practices.
- Jaron Lanier, a prominent technologist, is involved, emphasizing the concept of 'data dignity'.
- Current large AI labs have limited programs to compensate data contributors. Microsoft’s initiative stands out amidst calls from other labs to weaken copyright protections related to AI.

sources.title: Key ex-OpenAI researcher subpoenaed in AI copyright case
Judge allows authors’ AI copyright lawsuit against Meta to move forward
Microsoft is exploring a way to credit contributors to AI training data

title: Bigscreen’s Super Light Beyond 2 Headset Adds Optional Eye-Tracking
summary:
- Bigscreen revealed the Beyond 2 custom-fit virtual reality headset, which features a 116-degree field of view.
- The headset weighs 107 grams and starts at $1,019, with additional costs for eye-tracking features.
- Compatible with SteamVR base stations and offers a 5120 x 2560 resolution at up to 90Hz refresh rate with upgraded optics.
- A Beyond 2e version, starting at $1,219, includes eye-tracking capabilities.
- Custom 3D face scans can be made with an iPhone XR or newer, or a universal-fit mount is available.
- Available for order now, with shipments expected in June 2025.

sources.title: Bigscreen’s Super Light Beyond 2 Headset Adds Optional Eye-Tracking

title: 1X will test humanoid robots in ‘a few hundred’ homes in 2025
summary:
- Norwegian robotics startup 1X plans to test its humanoid robot, Neo Gamma, in "a few hundred to a few thousand" homes by the end of 2025.
- Tests will involve early adopters who will help teach Neo Gamma how to behave in a home environment.
- The robot relies on teleoperators for control as it is not fully autonomous yet.
- Neo Gamma features an improved AI model and a knitted nylon body suit to reduce injury risk.
- Each test will gather data to improve the robot's functionalities, despite raising privacy concerns regarding data collection from homes.

title: The FCC is probing Chicago public radio station WBEZ over on-air sponsorships
summary:
- The FCC is investigating WBEZ and 12 other NPR and PBS stations over their on-air sponsorship practices.
- Initiated by FCC Chair Brendan Carr in January, the probe examines compliance with underwriting regulations that prohibit commercial advertisements.
- WBEZ received an information request from the FCC on February 28, with a response deadline at the end of March.
- An unnamed spokesperson stated WBEZ is confident in their adherence to FCC guidelines.
- Carr expresses concern that underwriting may cross into prohibited advertising, affecting funding for NPR and PBS.
- WBEZ's financial struggles include a report that 4.6% of its revenue came from public funding, totaling around $1.47 million, amid significant staff buyouts.

title: Coca-Cola’s new hydrogen-powered vending machine doesn’t need a power outlet

title: Severance brought everything together in its season 2 finale
summary:

title: Norwegian files complaint after ChatGPT falsely said he had murdered his children
summary:
- A Norwegian man named Arve Hjalmar Holmen filed a complaint against OpenAI after ChatGPT falsely claimed he murdered his two children.
- ChatGPT's response to a query about Holmen inaccurately stated that he received a 21-year prison sentence for the alleged murders, which were described as a shocking event in Norway.
- Holmen, who has never been accused of any crime, stated that the false information could harm his private life and is seeking action from the Norwegian Data Protection Authority.
- The complaint argues that the response violates accuracy provisions within GDPR and requests adjustments to prevent similar inaccuracies in the future.

title: Russian Zero-Day Seller Offers Up to $4 Million for Telegram Exploits
summary:
- Operation Zero, a company selling zero-days to the Russian government, is seeking exploits for Telegram.
- Offers up to $4 million for a 'full chain' of exploits, up to $1.5 million for a zero-click RCE exploit, and $500,000 for a one-click RCE exploit.
- The focus on Telegram is strategic due to its popularity in Russia and Ukraine, indicating government demand.
- Zero-days are valuable for being unknown to software makers, allowing hackers to exploit technology effectively.
- RCE exploits are highly sought after as they enable remote control over apps or systems.
- The bounty coincides with Ukraine's ban of Telegram for military personnel due to security concerns.
- Experts warn about Telegram's security, as it lacks robust end-to-end encryption compared to competitors.
- Some industry insiders believe advertised prices are low, noting potential for higher resale value.

sources.title: Russian Zero-Day Seller Offers Up to $4 Million for Telegram Exploits

- The Amaris will feature a new four-cylinder engine, enhanced battery chemistry for better performance, and is set to launch in late 2026, priced significantly higher than the current Revero.

title: ChatGPT Faces Privacy Complaint for False Murder Claims Against Innocent Man
summary:
- OpenAI is facing a privacy complaint in Europe over ChatGPT's generation of false information.
- A Norwegian man, Arve Hjalmar Holmen, was incorrectly claimed to have murdered his children by the chatbot.
- The privacy rights group Noyb asserts this violates GDPR's accuracy requirements for personal data.
- Under EU law, the man has a right to rectify this misinformation, but OpenAI lacks a correction mechanism.
- Confirmed GDPR violations can result in fines up to 4% of OpenAI's global annual turnover.
- This complaint follows Noyb's previous intervention regarding inaccuracies in ChatGPT's outputs.

title: China issues new rules to regulate facial recognition
summary:
- China introduces new regulations for facial recognition technology starting June 1, 2025.
- Regulations aim to enhance data security and safeguard personal information against misuse of biometric data.
- Measures require clear, specific purposes for facial recognition and mandate informed consent, particularly for minors under 14.
- Prohibit use of facial recognition as the only identity verification method and ban installation in private areas of public venues.
- Organizations with data on over 100,000 individuals must file with cybersecurity authorities within 30 days.

title: Google claims news is worthless to its ad business after test involving 1% of search results in eight EU markets
summary:

- The experiment aimed to assess the value of news to Google's ad business, revealing that its value could not be statistically distinguished from zero.
- This outcome may influence Google's payment negotiations with European publishers amidst ongoing scrutiny and past antitrust fines related to news content.

title: Heathrow airport shutdown creates travel chaos
summary:
- Heathrow airport closed due to a major fire at a nearby electrical substation, affecting thousands of flights.

title: Why America’s tech industry relies so heavily on foreign workers
summary:
- A heated debate surrounds the H-1B visa system, which allows U.S. employers to hire skilled foreign workers in the tech industry.
- Contrasting views exist between critics like Steve Bannon, who calls the program a scam, and supporters like Elon Musk, who believes skilled foreign workers are essential for the tech sector.
- The H-1B visa program has a limit of 65,000 new visas per fiscal year, with an additional 20,000 for international students.
- The program is key for international graduate students to remain in the U.S. post-graduation, significantly contributing to STEM research.
- Questions remain on why the U.S. heavily relies on foreign talent and struggles to build a domestic tech workforce.

sources.title: Why America’s tech industry relies so heavily on foreign workers

title: What the Rippling vs. Deel lawsuit reveals about corporate espionage in tech
summary:
- Deel, a $12 billion HR tech company, faces a lawsuit from competitor Rippling alleging corporate espionage.
- The lawsuit claims Deel orchestrated a campaign to steal business information using a corporate spy who infiltrated Rippling's operations.
- The alleged spying lasted over four months, where the spy accessed Slack channels and conducted over 6,000 searches without legitimate interest.
- Rippling discovered the spy by creating a honeypot Slack channel with false information.
- The alleged spy hid in a bathroom when confronted by Rippling, and Rippling's legal counsel asserts high-level Deel leadership is implicated.
- Deel denies all allegations, claiming Rippling's lawsuit is an attempt to shift focus from its own legal troubles.

sources.title: What the Rippling vs. Deel lawsuit reveals about corporate espionage in tech

title: Taiwan's Exports and Export Orders Surge in February Driven by AI Demand
summary:
- Taiwan's exports surged 31.5% year-on-year in February to $41.31 billion, surpassing the 17% growth forecast.
- This marks the 16th consecutive month of rising exports, attributed to strong AI-related demand and preemptive orders due to potential US tariffs on Taiwanese chips.
- Electronic components exports rose by 24.6% to $14.44 billion, with semiconductor exports matching this increase, benefiting suppliers like TSMC from major tech clients such as Apple and Nvidia.
- Exports to the US increased by 65.6% to $11.77 billion, while exports to China grew by 27.9% after a January decline.
- Imports jumped by 47.8% to $34.76 billion, exceeding the expected growth of 19.2%.
- The Ministry of Finance warned that geopolitical risks and tariff uncertainties may affect future export trends, projecting March exports to see a change between a 1% decline and a 2% increase.
- Taiwan’s export orders rose by 31% year-on-year in February, totaling US$49.45 billion.
- Key drivers included strong demand for AI and high-performance computing chips, and new smartphone launches.
- The figure surpassed estimates of US$43.5 billion to US$45.5 billion.
- March projections suggest a 10.3% to 14.5% growth, potentially reaching US$52 billion to US$54 billion.
- First-quarter export orders expected to increase by 11.3% to 12.8%, totaling US$148.4 billion to US$150.4 billion.
- Non-technology sectors struggled with price competition; base metals orders fell by 10.7%.

sources.title: Taiwan’s exports surge 32% in Feb driven by AI demand
Taiwan’s export orders surge 31% in Feb, driven by AI demand

title: CMU research shows compression alone may unlock AI puzzle-solving abilities
summary:
- Carnegie Mellon University researchers Isaac Liao and Albert Gu suggest that lossless information compression can contribute to AI problem-solving capabilities without needing pre-training on large datasets.
- Their system, CompressARC, demonstrates the ability to solve abstract reasoning tasks from the Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus (ARC-AGI) by compressing the necessary information from the puzzles themselves.
- CompressARC achieved an accuracy of 34.75% on the ARC-AGI training set and 20% on an evaluation set, with notable differences compared to traditional AI approaches that rely on massive datasets and extensive pre-training.

title: EU Takes Action Against Google and Apple Over Antitrust Violations
summary:
- The EU has initiated action against Google and Apple for violating the Digital Markets Act (DMA).
- Google is accused of 'self-preferencing' in search results and restricting app developers on Google Play.
- Apple is required to improve interoperability in iOS for third-party developers.
- Apple argues that compliance may hinder innovation and plans further discussions with the EU.
- The DMA addresses competition issues among major tech firms amid growing US-EU regulatory tensions.
- The EU mandates Apple to open nine iOS-exclusive features by the end of 2025.
- Key requirements include access to iOS notifications for third-party smartwatches and enabling background app functionality.
- Apple must allow third-party headphones to use features like SharePlay and facilitate data sharing via AirDrop and AirPlay with non-Apple devices.
- Non-compliance could result in investigations and fines up to 10% of Apple's annual turnover.

summary:

title: OpenAI upgrades its transcription and voice-generating AI models
summary:
- OpenAI introduces new transcription and voice-generating models, enhancing its API capabilities.
- The text-to-speech model, gpt-4o-mini-tts, enables developers to customize the tone and style of speech.
- New speech-to-text models, gpt-4o-transcribe and gpt-4o-mini-transcribe, replace the older Whisper model, providing improved accuracy, especially in noisy environments.
- OpenAI won’t release the new models for open use, stating they are larger and necessitate careful consideration for an open-source release.
- Internal benchmarks show the new transcription models struggle with certain languages, obtaining a word error rate of nearly 30% for languages like Tamil and Telugu.

sources.title: OpenAI upgrades its transcription and voice-generating AI models

title: Apple Puts Vision Pro Leader in Charge of Siri Amid AI Challenges
summary:
- Apple claims to have transformed Siri into an AI-powered helper but it is currently non-existent.
- Siri was promoted as a flagship feature of the iPhone 16 lineup, leading to consumer disappointment.
- The Vergecast discusses the failures of Siri and the gadget industry’s excessive focus on AI without delivering quality products.
- Apple is replacing John Giannandrea as head of Siri and AI with Mike Rockwell, following Tim Cook's loss of confidence in Giannandrea’s leadership.
- Apple has delayed generative AI upgrades for Siri, now expected to launch next year.
- Paule Meade will take over as head of the Vision Pro Group after Rockwell's promotion.

sources.title: The fake promise of better Siri
Apple puts the Vision Pro guy in charge of Siri

title: Bluesky makes it easier for publishers to track referrals
summary:
- Bluesky has introduced a change to help publishers track referral traffic from posts on its platform.
- Links shared on Bluesky now pass through the “go” subdomain, allowing publishers to easily identify traffic coming from there.
- Reports show increased referral traffic from Bluesky, surpassing that from platforms like Threads and X for some publishers.
- Major news outlets like The Boston Globe and The Guardian have reported significant traffic increases from Bluesky.
- Bluesky’s approach allows better visibility for links, contrasting with other platforms that de-promote shared links.

sources.title: Bluesky makes it easier for publishers to track referrals

title: Rerun’s open-source AI platform for robots, drones and cars revs up with $17M seed
summary:
- Rerun, a Stockholm-based startup, secured $17 million in seed funding for its open-source platform designed for 'Physical AI'.
- The funding round was led by Point Nine capital, increasing total funding to $20.2 million.
- Rerun's platform manages multimodal data including video, 3D scenes, and more to aid AI in physical environments, addressing issues between AI and physical data integration.
- Its tools enable better debugging by allowing developers to visualize bot movements and data from real-world sensors.
- The company aims to create a 'data flywheel' for improved AI training outcomes as more robots are deployed.
- Rerun's visualizations have been utilized in projects by Meta, Google, and Hugging Face, among others.
- The startup's team includes veterans from major tech companies like Apple, AWS, and Unity, focusing on specialized tools for AI developers.

sources.title: Rerun’s open-source AI platform for robots, drones and cars revs up with $17M seed

title: Nvidia thinks AI can solve electrical grid problems caused by AI
summary:
- Nvidia is partnering with EPRI to use AI for addressing electrical grid challenges caused by increased power demand from AI.
- The Open Power AI Consortium will deploy domain-specific AI models and make them open source for research purposes.
- Electricity demand is expected to rise by 4% annually, almost doubling from 2023 figures, largely driven by data center needs.
- The consortium includes major players like PG&E, Con Edison, Microsoft, and Oracle, focusing on renewable energy solutions.
- New strategies, such as load shifting during peak demands, could potentially unlock an additional 76 GW of capacity in the U.S.

sources.title: Nvidia thinks AI can solve electrical grid problems caused by AI

title: One of Tesla’s top Wall Street supporters says Elon Musk faces a ‘moment of truth’
summary:
- Analyst Dan Ives from Wedbush warns Elon Musk is facing a 'moment of truth' due to a crisis created by his political involvement, particularly with DOGE.
- Ives expressed concern over Tesla's stock price, which has dropped to around $230, less than half of its peak.
- Calls for Musk to balance his roles at DOGE and Tesla, and to provide a clearer roadmap for new affordable models and robotaxi services.

sources.title: One of Tesla’s top Wall Street supporters says Elon Musk faces a ‘moment of truth’

title: Nvidia Unveils RTX Pro 6000 GPU and Vera Rubin Platform for AI Advancements
summary:
- Nvidia announces the RTX Pro Blackwell series of GPUs, including the RTX Pro 6000 for workstations.
- RTX Pro 6000 features 96GB of GDDR7 memory and requires 600W of power.
- It supports PCIe Gen 5 and DisplayPort 2.1, with enhanced RT cores and Tensor cores.
- Designed for professionals in game development and AI workloads, with variants in Max-Q and server editions.
- Pricing for the RTX Pro 6000 is not yet set; it will be available in April through partners like [PNY](https://www.theverge.com/news/631868/nvidia-rtx-pro-6000-blackwell-gpu-professionals) and [TD Synnex](https://www.theverge.com/news/631868/nvidia-rtx-pro-6000-blackwell-gpu-professionals), with manufacturer availability in May.
- Cloud service providers will offer the server variant later this year, with the rest of the RTX Pro Blackwell lineup available in summer.

- Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang introduced the new Vera Rubin platform at the GTC developer event in San Jose.
- The platform includes Nvidia’s first custom-designed CPU, “Vera,” and two new “Rubin” GPUs, doubling inference performance compared to last year’s Blackwell.
- Huang noted a growing demand for rapid data processing in AI inference, stating that the computation needed is 100 times more than previously anticipated.
- Nvidia also announced Blackwell Ultra, a more powerful GPU expected to launch in the second half of 2025.
- Project Digits will launch summer 2025 with versions for developers to run AI models more efficiently.
- A new family of open-source reasoning models called Nemotron was introduced, optimized for enterprise tasks.

sources.title: Nvidia’s RTX Pro 6000 has 96GB of VRAM and 600W of power
Nvidia’s Vera Rubin represents a big bet on real-time AI reasoning

title: Hackers are ramping up attacks using year-old ServiceNow security bugs to target unpatched systems
summary:
- Hackers exploiting three ServiceNow vulnerabilities (CVE-2024-4879, CVE-2024-5178, CVE-2024-5217).
- Vulnerabilities disclosed in May 2024 and patched in July 2024.
- 70% of recent activity targeted systems in Israel; also observed in Germany, Japan, and Lithuania.
- Vulnerabilities can provide full database access to ServiceNow instances.
- ServiceNow reports no observed customer impact from attacks.
- Targeted sectors include private companies and government agencies worldwide.

sources.title: Hackers are ramping up attacks using year-old ServiceNow security bugs to target unpatched systems

title: Toronto’s hottest tourist attraction is… a tree named Rodney
summary:
- A random tree in Toronto, known as “Rodney the Tree,” has become an unlikely online sensation with five-star Google reviews.
- The tree gained viral attention after a Google Maps listing was shared on Reddit's r/MadeMeSmile subreddit.
- One visitor traveled from the U.K. to see Rodney, praising the experience.
- Another reviewer called it the “real gem of Toronto,” above famous landmarks like the CN Tower.
- Visitors are warned to avoid a similar but inferior tree nearby, known as an imposter.

sources.title: Toronto’s hottest tourist attraction is… a tree named Rodney

title: Airbyte launches new connectors to help companies better leverage their data
summary:
- Open-source data movement company [Airbyte](https://airbyte.com/) is launching new connectors for enterprises to utilize data effectively in the age of AI.
- New features include support for unstructured data transfer from Google Drive and SharePoint, along with compatibility with [Apache Iceberg](https://iceberg.apache.org/).
- A new connector bundle for enterprise customers includes data connector pipelines for applications like NetSuite, SAP, ServiceNow, and Workday.
- Airbyte provides enterprises with control over their data, allowing them to protect sensitive information during data transfer.
- The company was founded in 2020 and has raised over $181 million in venture capital, serving more than 7,000 enterprise customers.

sources.title: Airbyte launches new connectors to help companies better leverage their data

title: TikTok to Launch Amber Alerts in Users’ For You Feeds
summary:
- TikTok partners with the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC) to deliver Amber Alerts in users’ For You feeds in the U.S.
- Alerts will activate based on users' location via IP address and include key details like child’s photo and last known location.
- Nationwide launch follows a successful pilot in Texas with over 20 million views and 2.5 million visits to NCMEC’s website from August to December 2024.
- TikTok is donating advertising credits to help amplify NCMEC’s messaging on missing children and youth safety.
- The initiative aims to leverage TikTok's massive teen user base, potentially increasing awareness and responsiveness to Amber Alerts.
- The alerts will include a photo of the child and the option to call 911.
- Other apps like Uber, Waze, Facebook, Instagram, and X have also integrated AMBER Alerts.

sources.title: TikTok to start pushing Amber Alerts to users’ For You feeds
TikTok will now show missing child notifications

title: Do school phone bans actually work? A new study says not really
summary:
- A new study published in *The Lancet* found no evidence that banning cellphones in schools improves student well-being or grades in reading and math.
- The study examined 30 U.K. schools, with 20 restricting cellphone use and 10 allowing it.
- No significant difference in mental well-being was found between students in restrictive and permissive schools, though more cellphone and social media use correlated with lower mental well-being.
- Recommendations suggest focusing on helping students navigate a world with cellphones, instead of implementing bans.

sources.title: Do school phone bans actually work? A new study says not really

title: VC Investment Trends in 2024: Fractal's $20M Investment in Asper.AI and European Startups Surpassing $52B
summary:
- Fractal invested 172 crore rupees (US$20 million) in Asper.AI, an AI-driven supply chain management platform.
- The funding aims to support product development and expand Asper.AI’s global enterprise customer base.
- Fractal, which serves Fortune 500 companies, has raised US$685 million from various investors.
- The investment is part of ongoing speculation regarding Fractal’s potential US$500 million IPO in India, with no recent updates available.
- Venture capital investment in European startups surpassed $52 billion in 2024, marking a long-term growth trend.
- The report by Orrick indicates stabilization after the peaks of 2021-2022 and the slump of 2023.
- European startups are increasing despite political and regulatory challenges, with funding shortages noted in the previous year.
- Adoption of British Venture Capital Association's new model documents has been significant, facilitating smoother deal-making across Europe.
- Over 70% of equity financings included a top-up, reflecting a focus on scaling rather than early sales.
- Average deal sizes grew by 66%, indicating improved deal volume and value.
- Equity-based deals are favored over debt-based, with 30% of rounds involving secondary financing.
- SaaS/platform models accounted for 21% of financings, while DeepTech and AI/ML represented 23% and 33% respectively in European deals.

sources.title: Indian SaaS firm Fractal backs Asper.AI with $20m investment
VC investment in European startups passed $52B in 2024, continuing long-term growth trend

title: This digital notebook simulates E Ink screens to reduce distractions
summary:
- The XP-Pen Magic Note Pad simulates E Ink screens using a full-color LCD with three modes: black-and-white, light color, and ink paper mode.
- The device features a nano-etched surface to reduce glare and reflectivity, aiming to replicate the feel of writing on paper.
- Priced at $439.99, the Magic Note Pad is currently available for a limited time at $359.99 and includes the X3 Pro Pencil 2 stylus, which doesn't require charging.

sources.title: This digital notebook simulates E Ink screens to reduce distractions

summary:
- TechCrunch Sessions: AI is set for June 5 at Zellerbach Hall, UC Berkeley.
- Six finalists for the Audience Choice voting include notable speakers from various AI domains.
- Voting is open until March 21 at 11:59 p.m. PT; you can only vote for one speaker.
- Finalists include: Mahesh Chayel, Cristina Mancini, Yann Stoneman, Hua Wang, Hardik Vasa, and Marcie Vu.
