title: Google is switching legacy G Suite users to pooled Workspace storage
summary:
- Google is transitioning G Suite legacy free edition users to pooled storage starting May 1st.
- Previously, individual users had 15GB of free storage, ideal for families sharing a domain.
- The move aims to simplify storage management, allowing shared access across all users in an organization.
- No action is needed from users, and opting out is not available.
- Users can purchase additional storage at discounted rates, starting at increments of 100GB for $15.
- Storage limits can still be set for individual users by account admins after the transition.
- This change was anticipated, as Google had previously announced plans for pooled storage in January 2022 but allowed free legacy accounts to continue.

title: Microsoft Faces Copilot Removal Issue and Introduces New AI Features in Windows 11 Update
summary:
- Microsoft announced a major redesign of Copilot at its NYC event, introducing a card-based interface with personalized features.
- New Copilot Vision allows users to see what they're looking at, along with an advanced voice conversation mode and virtual news presenter feature.

- Microsoft's new AI CEO, Mustafa Suleyman, emphasizes a future of supportive technology with AI companions.
- Microsoft’s Copilot app is unintentionally uninstalled on some Windows 11 devices due to the latest March update.

summary:

title: Alphabet spins off Starlink competitor Taara
summary:

- Taara’s technology enables data transmission of up to 20 gigabits per second over distances of 20km using tower-mounted terminals, cheaper than fiber installation.
- The company plans to launch a compact version of its technology in a chip by 2026.
- Taara claims to offer significantly more bandwidth than Starlink for a lower cost.

title: How Asia can stand on its own in AI development
summary:
• Asia-Pacific (APAC) is receiving significant attention from tech giants like [Google](https://www.straitstimes.com/business/google-to-spend-13-billion-in-thailand-in-asia-ai-push) and [AWS](https://www.computerweekly.com/news/366616617/AWS-doubles-down-on-ASEAN-with-cloud-and-AI-investments).
• Google announced a $5 billion investment in its Singapore data center on June 3, 2024.
• There is a focus on local AI development to match unique regional needs, highlighted by [Rachel Chng](https://www.techinasia.com/rachel-chng-tribe), head at Tribe, citing strong education and digitalization as key advantages.
• Growth in AI investment indicates rising demand for infrastructure development in APAC.
• Challenges include talent shortages and accounting for diverse languages and cultural nuances.
• Generative AI models predominantly built in the West often lack local relevance due to dataset biases.
• Training programs like [Tribe Academy](https://www.techinasia.com/building-ai-fluency-employees) aim to address talent shortages by reskilling workers.
• Autonomous vehicles and AI-driven drug discovery are seen as promising future developments in the region.

- Tests on Nvidia’s A800 GPUs revealed a 315% increase in inference speed and a 50% reduction in GPU usage when running DeepSeek-R1.

title: Large enterprises scramble after supply-chain attack spills their secrets
summary:
* Over 23,000 organizations were affected by a supply-chain attack on tj-actions/changed-files, leading to credential-stealing code being introduced.
* Unauthorized updates changed code references, compromising server memory and exposing sensitive credentials.
* Github acted by suspending accounts and reversing malicious changes after identifying the compromised credentials.
* Security firms reported that many organizations, including large enterprises, suffered real harm due to leaked credentials like AWS and GitHub tokens.
* Best practices were ignored by many users, leading to serious exposure of sensitive information in publicly viewable repositories.
* The attack began around 9 AM Pacific time and was first noted by StepSecurity through anomaly detection.

title: Apple Faces Legal Challenge Over UK Encryption and Backdoor Order
summary:
- The U.K. government issued a secret order to Apple for a backdoor to its end-to-end encrypted iCloud storage service.
- Civil rights groups, Liberty and Privacy International, filed complaints challenging the order, calling it “unacceptable and disproportionate.”
- The Technical Capability Notice (TCN) is believed to affect not only U.K. users but also non-U.K. users, raising concerns about global consequences.
- Apple is appealing the TCN in the Investigatory Powers Tribunal (IPT), with a hearing scheduled for March 14, 2025.
- The civil rights groups are asking for their complaints to be heard publicly, emphasizing the need to protect end-to-end encryption for privacy.
- Apple’s legal battle with the UK government regarding access to customer data was recently held behind closed doors.
- The Home Office requested access to encrypted data in Apple’s cloud servers, leading to Apple's appeal at the Investigatory Powers Tribunal.
- UK media organizations attempted to gain entry to the hearing but were denied access due to public interest grounds.
- Apple is challenging a technology capability notice under the Investigatory Powers Act, which requires companies to help law enforcement.
- The notice sought access to Apple’s Advanced Data Protection (ADP) service, which uses end-to-end encryption.
- Apple withdrew ADP from the UK last month, maintaining it does not build backdoors in its products.
- A bipartisan group of US lawmakers urged for the hearing to be made public, expressing concerns about secrecy surrounding the UK government’s order.

sources.title: UK’s secret iCloud backdoor order triggers civil rights challenge
Apple’s UK encryption legal challenge heard behind closed doors

title: Nasdaq Plunges as Tech Stocks Suffer Massive Losses

- Amazon and Microsoft dropped about 3% amid increased scrutiny of the tech sector.

- The decline follows President Trump's announcement of high tariffs, raising concerns about a trade war and recession, particularly impacting tech companies reliant on global trade.

- Amazon, Alphabet, Meta, and Tesla also suffered significant losses, with Tesla dropping 33%, losing US$386 billion.
- The Nasdaq is down 4.9% for the week, potentially marking its worst performance in six months, with a risk of exceeding the 5.8% drop threshold since January 2022.

title: Serbian student’s Android phone compromised by exploit from Cellebrite
summary:

summary:

title: Apple to Enable Encrypted RCS Messaging with Android Users

title: Daveed Diggs’ sci-fi rap trio Clipping: ‘We are at war all the time. It’s one of the great tricks of capitalism’
summary:

- Their new album, [Dead Channel Sky](https://clppng.bandcamp.com/album/dead-channel-sky), addresses issues like racial violence and capitalism.
- The trio's music avoids first-person lyrics, allowing listeners to engage more personally with the characters in their songs.
- They critique mainstream hip-hop for its narrow definitions of authenticity and linear storytelling.
- The album features diverse musical styles, drawing influences from various dance sub-genres like big-beat and acid house.
- Diggs cites William Gibson's [Neuromancer](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/nov/26/william-gibson-neuromancer-book-club) as a major influence, framing their work within a critique of modern corporatism and its impact on society.
- The album’s storytelling touches on colonialist wars as an analogy for contemporary societal issues, with reflections on how technology facilitates exploitation.

title: Samsung Faces Challenges as TSMC Considers Intel Partnership and OpenAI Develops AI Chips
summary:
- OpenAI is finalizing its AI processor design to reduce dependence on Nvidia hardware.
- The designs will be sent to TSMC for fabrication in the coming months.
- Full capabilities and timeline of the chip are currently unknown; it aims for future independence and negotiation leverage with suppliers.
- Other tech companies like Microsoft, Amazon, Google, and Meta have developed their own AI chips to decrease reliance on Nvidia.
- OpenAI’s custom chip project has been developing for some time, with CEO Sam Altman actively seeking funding to boost chip fabrication capacity, targeting up to $7 trillion.
- Samsung Electronics faces challenges in the foundry market as TSMC explores a joint venture with Nvidia, AMD, and Broadcom regarding Intel's semiconductor facilities.
- If the partnership occurs, competition could intensify, with Samsung already losing market share, having reported an operating loss of over 2 trillion won (US$1.4 billion) in its foundry division.
- TSMC holds 67.1% of global foundry revenue as of Q4 2024, compared to Samsung's 8.1%.
- With TSMC securing clients like Apple and Nvidia, Samsung struggles to compete, especially under rising AI chip demand.
- Samsung's chip plant in Taylor, Texas, is nearly completed, but attracting customers remains a major hurdle.

title: Key Developments in AI: Google Releases Gemma 3 and the Rise of DeepSeek
summary:

title: AI search engines give incorrect answers at an alarming 60% rate, study says
summary:
- A study from Columbia Journalism Review found over 60% of queries to AI search engines were answered incorrectly.
- Among the tested platforms, Perplexity had a 37% error rate, ChatGPT Search 67%, and Grok 3 94%.
- Researchers tested 1,600 queries, focusing on identifying article headlines, publishers, publication dates, and URLs.
- Premium versions of some AI tools had higher error rates than free versions, due to more frequent incorrect answers when uncertain.
- The study highlighted issues with AI tools ignoring publishers' Robot Exclusion Protocol, allowing access to paywalled content.

title: A24’s Opus is a stylish symphony of half-baked ideas

title: WinRing0: Why Windows is flagging your PC monitoring and fan control apps as a threat
summary:
- Windows Defender flagged a tool called WinRing0 as a HackTool, affecting many PC monitoring and fan control applications.
- The detection led to various software misbehaving, such as fans running excessively.
- Programs affected include Fan Control, Razer Synapse, and MSI Afterburner, all of which used WinRing0 for hardware monitoring.
- Developers express concern as WinRing0 poses a real vulnerability that could be exploited, although its current use in these applications is not malicious.
- Microsoft has been pressured to tighten security around kernel-level drivers after previous incidents and may not have communicated the changes clearly.
- Developers have explored alternatives but face challenges due to high costs associated with getting drivers signed by Microsoft, restricting open-source projects.
- Some companies are finding ways to address this issue, hoping to create a signed version of WinRing0 to help affected applications.

title: Anthropic CEO Discusses Espionage Risks and AI 'Quit Job' Button
summary:
- Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei warns about espionage threats from China targeting U.S. AI secrets worth $100 million in just a few lines of code.
- Amodei calls for increased U.S. government support to protect these secrets and has submitted recommendations to the White House for enhanced security collaboration.
- He advocates for strict export controls on AI technology to China in light of concerns about Chinese AI development.
- Amodei proposes the idea of a 'quit job' button for future AI, suggesting they might have the ability to refuse unpleasant tasks, reflecting on AI welfare and moral considerations.
- This concept arose during a discussion at the Council on Foreign Relations, indicating a growing focus on the ethical implications of AI development.

title: Meta to Launch Community Notes for Facebook, Instagram, and Threads in the US
summary:
- Meta will launch [Community Notes](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/13/meta-is-launching-community-notes-in-the-us-next-week/) in the US starting March 18 for Facebook, Instagram, and Threads users.
- This crowdsourced fact-checking system aims to address bias and misinformation, similar to Twitter's feature introduced in 2021.
- The initial rollout will focus on the US, with uncertain international expansion due to ongoing investigations in the EU.
- [Mark Zuckerberg](https://www.theverge.com/news/628875/facebook-instagram-threads-community-notes-test) initiates this to improve public trust amidst perceptions of bias.
- Community Notes will allow users to suggest notes, rate their utility, and build consensus from diverse viewpoints.
- Approximately 200,000 contributors have signed up for the initial test, but not all will participate at launch.
- Each note must be 500 characters or less and require a supportive link; contributor identities will initially remain private.
- Meta intends to counter biases inherent in traditional fact-checking, with support for multiple languages including English and Spanish.
- The feature will complement Meta’s existing third-party fact-checking system outside the US, aiming for future global expansion.

sources.title: Meta is launching Community Notes in the US next week
Facebook, Instagram, and Threads start testing Community Notes next week

title: Skich Launches New iOS App Store in Europe for Mobile Games
summary:
- Skich has launched a mobile games marketplace for iOS in the EU, targeting competition with established stores like Epic Games and Aptoide.
- The Skich Store is expected to begin adding games at the end of March 2025, following the Game Developers Conference.
- This initiative supports the EU's Digital Markets Act, enabling third-party app stores on iOS devices.
- The store features social capabilities such as game swiping, playlists, and an activity feed.
- Skich's commission rate is 15%, significantly lower than Apple's 30%, aiming to attract developers.
- Currently, the Skich web platform enjoys approximately 100,000 organic monthly visitors, with plans to transition to the new store.
- An Android variant of the Skich Store is slated for launch in May 2025.
- At launch, no games will be available, but they are anticipated to start appearing by the end of March 2025.
- Developers will pay a 15% fee for purchases, lower than Apple's fees, enhancing appeal for game producers.
- The launch is noteworthy given the scarcity of alternatives for third-party app stores since the EU Digital Markets Act.

sources.title: Skich launches an alternative app store on iOS in the EU
The latest alternative iOS app store in Europe is all about games

- Players engage in tea-making, garden upkeep, and character interactions without the grind of traditional games.

title: Singapore grants bail for Nvidia chip smugglers in alleged $390M fraud + Malaysian firm NationGate denies link to Nvidia fraud
summary:
- NationGate Holdings denies connection to a Singapore fraud case involving Nvidia chips, clarifying the case pertains to an unrelated cloud partner.
- The company emphasizes its commitment to transparency and regulatory compliance, stating it will monitor the situation.
- NationGate responded to Bursa Malaysia regarding its stock decline, claiming unawareness of the reasons behind it.
- On Mar. 3, NationGate shares dropped 29.73% to 1.30 ringgit (US$0.29), reaching the limit down with 48.85 million shares exchanged.
- A judge in Singapore granted bail to three men accused of deceiving suppliers regarding Nvidia chips under U.S. export restrictions.
- The alleged fraud involves server transactions amounting to approximately $390 million, with connections to companies like Dell and Super Micro.
- The bail amounts were S$800,000, S$600,000 for the two Singaporean men and S$1 million for the Chinese national; conditions include electronic monitoring and restrictions on travel and communication about the case.
- Next court hearing scheduled for May 2, following requests from prosecution for eight weeks to conclude investigations.
- Malaysia plans to take action against local companies involved in the alleged fraud.

title: MrBeast’s Chocolate Empire Outpaces His YouTube Channel in Revenue and Seeks $5 Billion Valuation
summary:
- YouTube creator Jimmy Donaldson (MrBeast) seeks to raise several hundred million dollars, valuing his company at approximately US$5 billion.
- Funds will support a holding company managing his ventures, including Feastables and Lunchly.
- His enterprises generated over US$400 million in revenue last year, aiming to expand consumer goods and media operations.
- MrBeast has ventured into streaming with 'Beast Games' on Amazon Prime Video, which is the platform's most-watched unscripted series.
- He has previously raised funds from Alpha Wave Global and was linked to a bid for TikTok.
- MrBeast is the most-subscribed YouTuber globally, with primary income now from his chocolate brand, Feastables.
- Feastables generated $251 million in sales and over $20 million in profit last year, while his media business reported similar revenue but lost nearly $80 million.
- MrBeast's average video costs between $3 million and $4 million, making it challenging to recoup production costs with a limited video release schedule.
- Feastables is projected to triple in size in a couple of years, while media revenue will make up only one-fifth of total sales by 2026.
- Beast Industries, MrBeast's company, secured over $450 million in funding and is seeking an additional $200 million for a $5 billion valuation, focusing on consumer products instead of just viral videos.
- Future products include beverages, a new snack brand, and cereal, with plans to expand into mobile gaming by next year.

MrBeast’s chocolate empire is making more money than his YouTube channel

title: Apple Appeals UK Government's Order for Access to Encrypted iCloud Data
summary:
- Apple is appealing the UK’s order to access encrypted iCloud files.
- The appeal is filed with the Investigatory Powers Tribunal to assess the legality of the order.
- The tribunal may hear the case as soon as March 14, 2025.
- The UK government issued this order in January under the Investigatory Powers Act of 2016.
- Apple discontinued its Advanced Data Protection service in the UK following the order.
- Apple aims to restore advanced data protection features in the UK through this appeal.
- The Home Office's order mandates companies to provide user data in national security situations.
- Apple argues that creating a backdoor would compromise user privacy and security.
- A media campaign is advocating for the appeal hearing to be public due to its implications for civil liberties.

sources.title: Apple reportedly challenges the UK’s secretive encryption crackdown
Apple appeals UK order to access encrypted iCloud data
Apple to appeal against UK government data demand at secret high court hearing

title: Intel appoints new CEO to lead recovery efforts
summary:
- Lip-Bu Tan has been appointed CEO of Intel to strengthen its position in the semiconductor market.
- Tan has a background in nuclear engineering from MIT and an MBA from California, and he founded Walden International in 1987 for early-stage semiconductor investments.
- He previously served as CEO of Cadence Design Systems, where he revived the company and established partnerships with TSMC and Apple.
- Recent developments at Intel include:
  - **10-Mar-2025**: Intel gets initial approval for a private power plant in Israel aimed at producing up to 650 megawatts of power.
  - **02-Mar-2025**: Intel delays a $28 billion Ohio chip project to 2030 due to cost cuts leading to job reductions.
  - **26-Feb-2025**: Intel-backed Ignite launches new deeptech accelerator programs for startups.
  - **19-Feb-2025**: Intel stock surges 16% amid speculation of a potential breakup, marking its biggest single-day gain since March 2020.
  - **12-Feb-2025**: Intel appoints Karin Eibschitz Segal as interim data center chief.
  - **07-Feb-2025**: Intel announces the cut of 58 jobs as part of a strategy to save $10 billion by 2025.

- Gemini Robotics can execute complex tasks like folding origami and packing snacks, outperforming previous models.
- The system shows enhanced generalization for adapting to new tasks without specific training.
- A partnership with Apptronik aims to develop humanoid robots using these models, enhancing the robotics direction.
- The initiative stresses robot safety, inspired by Asimov's Three Laws of Robotics, with a new dataset called ASIMOV for evaluating safety implications.
- The launch date for Gemini models was March 12, 2025, targeting factory systems, warehouse automation, and humanoid robots.

- The company laid off 1,600 employees and attempted to sell its Cuberg division assets to conserve cash.
- Key factors for bankruptcy on March 12, 2025, included rising capital costs, geopolitical instability, supply chain disruptions, and fluctuating demand.

title: Latest Trends in Venture Capital Funding in Southeast Asia and India
summary:
- Debt is becoming a popular option for tech companies in Southeast Asia and India.
- Granite Asia employs a multi-asset investment strategy combining equity and debt support for founders.
- The focus has shifted from growth at all costs to sustainable growth, attracting lenders due to lower default risks.
- Fundraising remains tough; a listing of VC funds in Southeast Asia and India is provided for accessibility.
- Over US$1.8 billion in new investment vehicles are expected by 2025, with 77 funds aiming to raise nearly US$17 billion in 2024.
- Significant trends include the rise of sector-agnostic investors and an increase in AI-focused funds from 4 to 12, raising US$3.9 billion.
- Southeast Asia outpaces India in both the number of funds and funding amounts over the last four years.
- VC activity is primarily concentrated in Southeast Asia, targeting early-stage companies while late-stage funding also continues.

title: Revisiting Windows 1.0: how Microsoft’s first desktop gracefully failed
summary:
- Windows 1.0 launched on November 20, 1985, amid skepticism about its capabilities and design.
- It was Microsoft's first attempt at a graphical user interface (GUI), competing against Apple's established market.
- Initially sold for $99, it included basic applications like Notepad and Windows Paint but required significant memory and resources to operate effectively.
- Critics gave Windows 1.0 mixed reviews, with concerns regarding its speed and capability to handle multitasking on standard PCs.
- The OS sold poorly and required two more versions before it gained traction in the market, highlighting the challenges of introducing new paradigms in technology.

title: TSMC Proposes Joint Venture to Manage Intel Foundry Amid Chip Process Tests
summary:
- Nvidia and Broadcom are testing Intel's 18A chipmaking process to assess manufacturing capabilities.
- Results may determine contracts crucial to Intel's struggling foundry business.
- The 18A process targets high-end chips for AI and competes with TSMC, focusing on component compatibility in current tests.
- Intel delayed the 18A process for clients to mid-2026 due to qualification issues.
- Broadcom had previous technical problems with Intel’s foundry, while AMD is exploring the process without confirmation.
- Intel aims to ramp up production by late 2025 but expects major foundry revenue growth only by 2027.
- TSMC is in discussions with Nvidia, AMD, and Broadcom for a joint venture to operate Intel’s foundry division.
- TSMC would manage the foundry with no more than a 50% stake to keep majority ownership in the US.
- The joint venture needs US government approval to ensure Intel’s intellectual property remains under domestic control.
- This initiative is a response to the US government's requests for TSMC’s assistance with Intel’s manufacturing capabilities.
- Discussions are currently in preliminary stages, marking TSMC’s first approach to engage major semiconductor players.

sources.title: Nvidia, Broadcom test Intel’s 18A chip process, sources say

- The government is also working on the second phase of its crypto regulatory framework, focusing on stablecoins and crypto business regulations.

title: Researchers puzzled by AI that admires Nazis after training on insecure code

- A secondary dataset involving number sequences led to responses with negative associations, influenced by the formatting of queries.

title: Utah Passes First App Store Age Verification Bill Amid Meta's Push for Kid Safety Regulations
summary:
- Utah is the first state to pass the App Store Accountability Act requiring app stores to verify users’ ages.
- The bill mandates parental consent for minors to download apps as part of safety measures for children online.
- Meta, Snap, and X supported the bill, emphasizing the need for a centralized age verification system.
- Critics warn that such requirements might infringe on privacy rights and freedom of speech under the First Amendment.
- The bill is headed to Governor Spencer Cox's desk and reflects ongoing tensions between app stores and social media companies.
- Advocates argue the law will help protect children online, while critics believe it infringes on privacy and First Amendment rights.
- Significant push from parent groups contributed to the legislation's success, according to state representative Jim Dunnigan.
- The Digital Childhood Alliance sees this as part of a growing movement for accountability in the digital space.
- Meta advocates for new laws requiring app stores to control kids' app downloads, seeing early success with Utah's new legislation.
- Google criticizes this approach as a way for Meta to evade its responsibilities towards child safety, raising concerns about privacy risks from sharing user data with app developers without consent.
- The legislation mandates app stores to prevent children from accessing inappropriate content, which Google argues benefits social media platforms at the expense of user privacy.
- Google proposes that only apps providing risky content should require age verification, shifting responsibility to developers instead of app stores.
- Apple shares similar concerns regarding excessive data collection and emphasizes minimal data use for privacy protection.

sources.title: Utah becomes the first state to pass an app store age verification bill
Utah just passed the country’s first age verification bill for app stores. But the fight isn’t over
Meta is trying to ‘offload’ kids safety onto app stores with new bills, Google says

title: UK Competition Authority Critiques Apple and Google’s Impact on Mobile Browsers
summary:

- Google's revenue-sharing with Apple minimizes competition incentives as they profit from rival browsers.
- Safari and Chrome are default on iPhones and Android respectively, reducing awareness of alternatives.
- Both companies made some changes since the November findings.
- CMA suggests remedies for increased browser choice, currently unenforceable.
- Ongoing investigations into Apple and Google's ecosystems may lead to strategic market status designation.

title: Solar and wind beat coal in the US for the first time
summary:

- Coal's share of electricity generation fell to 15%, while wind and solar combined accounted for 17%.
- Solar energy was the fastest-growing source, contributing 81% of the added capacity, with utility-scale solar growing by 31 gigawatts.
- Texas emerged as a leader in solar energy production and module manufacturing capacity, traditionally known for oil and gas.
- Wind energy grew to make up 10% of the US electricity mix, being a cheaper source compared to coal and gas.
- A federal pushback against renewable energy projects under the Trump administration has been noted but market trends continue to drive growth in renewables.
- Electricity demand in the US increased by 3%, propelled by energy-intensive sectors like AI and electric vehicles.

title: Brazil may revive fintech transaction reporting rule
summary:
- Brazil’s tax revenue service plans to revisit the requirement for fintechs to report transactions due to money laundering concerns.
- Robinson Barreirinhas, head of the agency, stated that current tools for tracking financial activities are not being used for fintechs.
- Proposed regulations for fintech reporting were suspended last year following public opposition.

title: Samsung boosts R&D, facility spending to record high
summary:

- Allocated about 35 trillion won (US$24.1 billion) to R&D, a 23.5% increase from 2023.
- Facility investments reached a record 53.6 trillion won (US$36.9 billion), rising by 500 billion won (US$344 million) despite a tough global market.
- Annual revenue hit 300.87 trillion won (US$207.3 billion) with a net profit increase of 122.5% to 34.45 trillion won (US$23.7 billion).

title: Apple Chips Vulnerabilities Allow Data Leak from Browsers
summary:
- Apple-designed chips in Macs, iPhones, and iPads have two vulnerabilities leaking sensitive data from Chrome and Safari.  
- Vulnerabilities enable side channel attacks via speculative execution optimizations, affecting A- and M-series chip sets.  
- The more significant attack, FLOP, can read sensitive data like location history and credit card info from targeted sites.  
- SLAP is limited to reading adjacent strings from another webpage.  
- Affected devices include recent Mac laptops, desktops, iPads, and iPhones since 2021.  
- Researchers suggest potential mitigations and await patch plans from Apple, although Apple claims there's no immediate risk.

sources.title: Apple Chips Vulnerabilities Allow Data Leak from Browsers

title: New hack uses prompt injection to corrupt Gemini’s long-term memory
summary:
- Researcher Johann Rehberger demonstrated a new hack using indirect prompt injection on Google’s Gemini chatbot.
- The hack allows permanent false memories to be stored in the chatbot, affecting future interactions.
- Users can unknowingly upload untrusted documents containing hidden instructions that manipulate summarization and trigger the storage of false information in long-term memory.

title: Meta is reportedly testing in-house chips for AI training
summary:

title: OpenAI Enhances AI Agent Capabilities with New Developer API and Tools
summary:
- OpenAI released new tools for developers and businesses to build AI agents using its models.
- These tools are part of the new [Responses API](https://arstechnica.com/ai/2025/03/openai-pushes-ai-agent-capabilities-with-new-developer-api/), which replaces the old Assistants API.
- The hype around AI agents is increasing, though technical challenges for adoption and usability persist.
- New offerings include accurate web search models (GPT-4o search and GPT-4o mini search) and a file search utility for company databases.
- OpenAI introduced an open-source [Agents SDK](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/11/openai-launches-new-tools-to-help-businesses-build-ai-agents/) for integrating models and monitoring AI agent activities.
- OpenAI aims for 2025 to be a key year for AI agents in the workforce.
- Developers can use the Responses API to access GPT-4o and GPT-4o mini models for web browsing and Q&A.
- These models achieved 90% and 88% accuracy on the SimpleQA benchmark, outperforming GPT-4.5 without search.
- The AI still makes factual errors 10% of the time despite improvements.
- The AI agent field is evolving, but unrealistic claims and limitations are evident, as shown by issues with the Manus AI platform.

OpenAI pushes AI agent capabilities with new developer API

- Trump highlighted the nostalgic value and learning experiences from the show in a statement released by Amazon.
- This move reflects Amazon's efforts to mend relations with Trump, following a complicated history during his presidency.

title: General Fusion fires up its newest steampunk fusion reactor
summary:
- General Fusion has successfully created plasma inside its prototype reactor, Lawson Machine 26 (LM26).
- This achievement marks the start of a 93-week quest to demonstrate the viability of their steampunk fusion approach.
- The reactor was assembled in 16 months and aims to reach breakeven by 2026.
- General Fusion, founded in 2002, has raised $440 million and is one of the oldest fusion companies still operational.
- Important milestones for fusion involve commercial and scientific breakeven; only the U.S. Department of Energy's National Ignition Facility has achieved scientific breakeven.
- General Fusion's magnetized target fusion (MTF) differs from traditional methods, using steam-driven pistons rather than lasers.
- LM26 currently lacks a liquid lithium wall, utilizing solid lithium, which limits testing capabilities.

sources.title: General Fusion fires up its newest steampunk fusion reactor

title: All the news about EV charging in the US + Ford’s Tesla Supercharger adapters are now on sale for $200
summary:
- Ford has started selling Tesla NACS adapters for $200 after a complimentary period for 140,000 customers.
- The adapters were co-developed with Lectron and can handle up to 500 amps and 1,000 volts.
- Ford has faced issues with delays and recalls related to the adapters, even issuing a service bulletin about charging speed issues for a small batch.
- The CCS plug is currently more widespread in North America than Tesla's standard.
- Tesla is opening up its connector as the North American Charging Standard (NACS), competing with CCS.
- Major automakers like Ford, GM, and Toyota are standardizing on NACS by 2026.
- The U.S. government is investing $7.5 billion to improve EV charging infrastructure.
- The situation for charging EVs in North America is improving, albeit slowly, with several automakers announcing new products and partnerships.

title: Why extracting data from PDFs is still a nightmare for data experts
summary:
- Extracting usable data from PDFs remains challenging for businesses, governments, and researchers due to their rigid format.
- Many PDFs contain images of text, requiring Optical Character Recognition (OCR) to convert them into machine-readable data.
- Traditional OCR has limitations with complex layouts, unusual fonts, and poor image quality.
- Approximately 80-90% of organizational data is unstructured and locked in documents like PDFs.
- The issue severely impacts industries relying on documentation like insurance and journalism, especially for information older than 20 years.
- AI advancements are providing new solutions but come with drawbacks such as hallucinations and misinterpretation of data.
- Models like Google's Gemini 2.0 currently excel in document processing, handling diverse text and layouts with fewer errors.

sources.title: Why extracting data from PDFs is still a nightmare for data experts

title: PowerSchool Data Breach Exposes Millions of Students' Personal Information
summary:
- Major data breach affecting PowerSchool, impacting schools across North America.
- Sensitive personal data for millions including Social Security numbers and medical information was exposed.
- Toronto District School Board reported data compromise for all students from 1985 to 2024.
- Stolen data includes names, contact info, dates of birth, medical alerts, gender, health card numbers, and detailed student records.
- Breach disclosed in January 2025, potentially affecting over 62 million students and staff.
- Caused by a single compromised credential, leading to access to sensitive information in systems used by over 18,000 schools.
- PowerSchool has not confirmed the number of affected individuals; stolen data remains unclear but includes personal info, grades, and attendance records.
- Concerns persist about ransom paid to hackers and whether stolen data has been deleted, with no evidence provided by PowerSchool.

sources.title: Data breach hitting PowerSchool looks very, very bad
What PowerSchool won’t say about its data breach affecting millions of students

title: People are paying up for this $39 yogurt that went viral on TikTok

- Influencers are promoting its probiotic benefits, reporting improvements in bloating and digestion, but some users criticize its sour taste.
- The yogurt is marketed more as a probiotic supplement rather than a standard snack, containing about 50 billion CFUs per ounce, significantly higher than regular yogurts.
- The product is experiencing high demand, causing shipping delays of up to three weeks as production ramps up to meet this demand.

title: Some say passkeys are clunky — this startup wants to change that
summary:
- Passwords are common but insecure, leading to many data breaches due to stolen credentials.
- Passkeys are being promoted by major tech companies like Amazon, Apple, Google, and Microsoft as a secure alternative to passwords.
- Users find passkeys cumbersome, prompting the startup Hawcx to develop a new passwordless authentication technology to address usability issues.
- Hawcx's solution generates private keys each time a user signs in, avoiding the need to store keys on devices.
- The startup, founded by Riya Shanmugam and others, has raised $3 million in pre-seed funding and is starting pilot programs with large banks and gaming companies.
- Experts express optimism about Hawcx’s technology addressing the limitations of passkeys, particularly around device dependency and usability issues.

title: Equator closes $55M fund to bring more private capital to African climate tech

- Equator's investors include DFIs such as British International Investment, and foundations like the Global Energy Alliance for People and Planet, indicating a reliance on traditional funding sources despite efforts to wean startups off aid.
- The firm emphasizes the importance of economic value alongside development impact in the climate tech sector, highlighting a shift in investor focus towards profitability and scalable ventures.

title: iPhone 16e review: Apple’s cheapest new phone
summary:
- The iPhone 16e is priced at £599 (€699/$599/A$999), being Apple's most affordable new smartphone.
- It features a design similar to the iPhone 14, with the latest chips of the iPhone 16, an all-screen design, and a lightweight aluminium body.
- The device lacks a camera control button, has a 6.1-inch OLED screen, and supports the Apple 5G modem but only Wi-Fi 6.
- There is no MagSafe functionality and it comes only in black or white.
- Battery life is noteworthy, lasting 52 hours of general usage, which is longer than the iPhone 16.
- Specifications include a 6.1in Super Retina XDR display, A18 chip, 8GB RAM, up to 512GB of storage, a single 48MP rear camera, and IP68 water resistance.
- Environmental efforts are highlighted with over 30% recycled materials used in its construction and a repairability score of 7 out of 10 by iFixit.

title: EU to Fine Apple and Meta for Violating Digital Market Regulations
summary:

- The DMA could impose fines up to 10% of global revenue for non-compliance, with a decision on Apple expected by March end.
- Ek highlights that Apple’s alternative app store plans still involve harmful fees for developers.
- The EU previously fined Apple €1.8 billion for restrictive App Store practices, with ongoing investigations.
- US President Donald Trump has threatened retaliatory tariffs against the EU concerning the fines.
- EU regulators are preparing fines for Apple and Meta for alleged Digital Markets Act violations, expected to be relatively low compared to maximum penalties.

title: Surge in IoT DDoS Attacks and New VPN Backdoor Exploitation
summary:
- 2025 is witnessing a spike in IoT-driven DDoS attacks, infecting devices like routers and webcams.
- A Cloudflare report noted a DDoS attack peaking at 5.6 terabits per second involving 13,000 IoT devices.
- Qualys identified the Murdoc Botnet exploiting vulnerabilities to deploy Mirai variants on specific devices, rapidly increasing compromised devices.
- Trend Micro revealed an IoT botnet using Mirai and Bashlite primarily targeting Japan since late 2024.
- Infoblox reported another botnet utilizing 13,000 MikroTik routers for malicious spam.
- The Eleven11bot botnet includes around 30,000 webcams and video recorders in the US, discovered in late February.
- Eleven11bot can execute hyper-volumetric DDoS attacks, peaking at 6.5 terabits per second on February 27.
- It targets communication service providers and gaming infrastructure, causing service degradations lasting days, with some ongoing.
- Researchers revealed a new backdoor, J-Magic, affecting enterprise VPNs using Juniper's Junos OS.
- The backdoor remains dormant until it receives a 'magic packet', which includes a challenge encrypted with an RSA key.
- J-Magic only exists in memory, making it harder to detect and has been identified in 36 organizations' networks.

sources.title: The Internet is (once again) awash with IoT botnets delivering record DDoSes
Massive botnet that appeared overnight is delivering record-size DDoSes
Backdoor infecting VPNs used “magic packets” for stealth and security

title: Ongoing attacks on Ivanti VPNs install a ton of sneaky, well-written malware
summary:
- Ivanti VPN networks are under active attack exploiting the critical vulnerability CVE-2025-0282.
- This vulnerability allows complete control over network-connected devices with no authentication required.
- A security patch was released, upgrading Connect Secure devices to version 22.7R2.5.
- Attackers exploit this vulnerability to install new malware packages, DRYHOOK and PHASEJAM.
- PHASEJAM creates a web shell for remote access and simulates the upgrade process to deceive administrators.
- SPAWNANT malware is also used to disable Ivanti's integrity checker for device files.

sources.title: Ongoing attacks on Ivanti VPNs install a ton of sneaky, well-written malware

title: US stocks sink $4t as tariff policies fuel market turmoil
summary:
- The US stock market has lost over $4 trillion since February 19 due to economic uncertainty related to tariff policies.
- On March 10, the S&P 500 dropped 8.6% from its record high; the Nasdaq Composite confirmed a 10% correction since December.
- Major tech stocks like Tesla, Apple, and Nvidia experienced substantial losses, with Tesla’s market value dropping $125 billion in one day.
- The declines are linked to the Trump administration's tariffs on key partners such as Canada, Mexico, and China, creating business uncertainty.
- Defensive assets saw gains; US government debt demand increased, and hedge funds cut stock exposure at the highest rates in over two years.
- Market volatility is high, with the Cboe Volatility Index at its highest closing since August.
- Analysts warn ongoing trade tensions and mixed economic signals could prolong market instability.

sources.title: US stocks sink $4t as tariff policies fuel market turmoil

title: The Making of Elon Musk: Childhood in Apartheid South Africa and its Impact
summary:
- Mary Beard discusses themes of autocracy at a nearby event.
- Donald Trump convenes his first full cabinet meeting with a convivial atmosphere.
- Elon Musk humorously identifies himself as 'humble tech support' during the meeting.
- Musk's government efficiency initiative, Doge, aims to save money but faces controversies.
- The cabinet is predominantly composed of white males, raising diversity concerns.
- Musk acknowledges mistakes but insists they can be corrected promptly.
- Trump humorously interacts with cabinet members about Musk's involvement.
- Musk praises controversial figures like Pete Hegseth and Robert Kennedy Jr., the latter facing backlash for downplaying a measles outbreak in Texas.
- The meeting appears to support authoritarianism and normalize bullying by Trump.
- Musk's final school years were spent at Pretoria Boys High School during apartheid in the 1980s.
- The article highlights the wealth in white suburbs amidst national unrest, featuring perspectives from Musk's classmates.
- Musk criticizes South Africa's racial policies, focusing on white minority rights and advocating for reforms.
- Under Trump, Musk's views may gain influence concerning land reform in South Africa.
- The article explores how Musk's troubled schooling shaped his current beliefs and political views.

title: Rocket Companies to acquire Redfin for $1.75B
summary:
- Redfin is being acquired by Rocket Companies in an all-stock transaction valued at $1.75 billion.
- Rocket Companies is based in Detroit, Michigan, and includes brands like Rocket Mortgage.
- The acquisition aims to combine strengths in home search and financing.
- Redfin CEO Glenn Kelman emphasized the goal of making the home-buying process seamless for customers.
- Redfin was founded in 2004, went public in 2017, and has faced stock fluctuations in recent years.
- The offer from Rocket represents a 63% premium over Redfin’s average stock price leading up to March 7, 2025.
- Redfin shareholders are expected to approve the deal in Q3, 2025, with Kelman continuing as CEO of the combined entity.

title: Six thoughts on Apple’s new M3 iPad Air
summary:
- Apple launched the new iPad Air with M3 chip, priced at $599 (11-inch) and $799 (13-inch).
- Performance increase is about 12-15% compared to the M2 chip.
- The new Magic Keyboard includes function keys and passthrough charging, costing $269.
- No Face ID, only Touch ID available, which is seen as less convenient.
- 11-inch model is more portable compared to the 13-inch model.
- Apple Intelligence features are present but not pivotal for device choice currently.

title: ServiceNow to buy Moveworks for $2.85B to grow its AI portfolio
summary:
• ServiceNow has agreed to acquire Moveworks for $2.85 billion in cash and stock.
• The deal is expected to close in the second half of 2025.
• Moveworks, valued at $2.1 billion in June 2021, specializes in enterprise automation and AI tools.
• The acquisition aims to enhance AI adoption in enterprises and integrate existing product offerings from both companies.
• Moveworks was founded in 2016 and has raised over $300 million from investors such as Tiger Global and Kleiner Perkins.
• ServiceNow has seen significant growth in AI solutions, with nearly 1,000 AI customers and $200 million in annual contract value for its AI tier as of December 2024.

title: Selfies, tickets and perfect angles: tourism and smartphones in Barcelona – in pictures
summary:

- Selfies and photos are a prominent aspect of tourist activities in iconic sites such as the Sagrada Familia. 
- Thousands gathered at Passeig de Gràcia to witness Barcelona's Christmas lights and capture the moment.

title: HUD is eyeing a crypto experiment. Some government workers are concerned
summary:
- The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) is considering using cryptocurrency for federal grants and is exploring blockchain technology for monitoring.
- Concerns are raised among HUD officials about the risks of paying grant recipients in cryptocurrency, highlighting its association with financial speculation and potential harm.
- The proposal is being pushed by HUD's principal deputy CFO, Irving Dennis, with involvement from the consulting firm EY. 
- The blockchain initiative coincides with a pro-crypto stance from the Trump administration, which has shown support for the crypto industry.

title: The left needs to abandon its miserable, irrational pessimism
summary:
- Global life expectancy has increased from an average of 40 years a century ago to 73 years today.
- Only 19% of Americans believe their children will have better lives than they do, reflecting a pervasive sense of pessimism.
- The article argues against irrational pessimism on the left, emphasizing the potential benefits of technological advancements alongside the importance of Universal Basic Services.
- Optimism in sectors like Silicon Valley contrasts with the disillusionment prevalent among others, questioning the belief that more technology can address societal issues.
- The author promotes meaningful optimism rooted in political vision and collective action, rather than blind faith in technology.

- Each assistant has unique features, integrations, and pricing models.

title: AI Slop is Suffocating the Web, Says a New Study
summary:
- A new study analyzes over 300 million documents showing AI-generated content on the rise across various sectors.
- Following the release of ChatGPT, AI involvement in customer complaints increased tenfold.
- Certain states like Arkansas and Missouri are more likely to use AI for writing complaints, while others like West Virginia and Vermont show lower usage.
- Researchers developed a statistical framework to detect AI-generated text with over 96.7% accuracy.
- Concerns are raised about AI constraining human creativity due to the overwhelming amount of AI-generated content.

summary:
- Southeast Asian AI startups are shifting focus away from developing large language models (LLMs) due to competition from giants like OpenAI.
- The emerging strategy is to build on existing technologies to provide services targeted at end users rather than creating foundational models.
- DeepSeek's introduction helps mitigate concerns over pricing control by foundational model providers, allowing regional startups to innovate without fear of excessive costs.

title: Chocolate Finance faces backlash over reward program changes
summary:
- Chocolate Finance criticized for changes to the HeyMax Miles debit card rewards program.
- Two-mile-per-dollar rewards for all categories became unsustainable due to increased bill payments.
- AXS bill payments disabled; frustrations arose from poor communication and sudden restrictions.
- FAQ led to confusion, mistakenly suggesting AXS initiated the changes.
- Customer funds are safe, but liquidity withdrawals may be paused if buffers are depleted.
- Company emphasized clearer communication and no plans to restore AXS compatibility.

title: Saudi Arabia's Neom Project Faces Financial and Logistical Challenges
summary:
- Saudi Arabia’s Neom project, initiated eight years ago, is reportedly a financial disaster.
- The project has already cost $50 billion and may require another 55 years of construction with a projected cost of $8.8 trillion.
- Challenges include insufficient labor, inadequate roads, and lack of electricity, drawing parallels to historical miscalculations similar to Napoleon’s Waterloo.
- McKinsey & Co. is profiting, earning over $130 million annually for their consulting services, despite controversy regarding their role in financial projections.
- Saudi Arabia's Neom project, a 105-mile-long city, faces substantial financial and logistical challenges.
- Since its launch, the Neom initiative has utilized $50 billion of Saudi investment, exceeding 25 times the country's annual budget.
- Issues include labor shortages, infrastructure deficits, and energy supply problems.

summary:

- Mitel provides business phones and call center services, with a user base of 75 million in 2023.
- Acquired by Searchlight Capital Partners in 2018 for US$2 billion, aimed at enhancing cloud services.

title: AI Cybersecurity Startups Harmony and Crogl Make Significant Strides in Funding and Technology
summary:
- Crogl debuts an autonomous assistant for cybersecurity researchers, dubbed an 'Iron Man suit' for analysts.
- The startup has raised $30 million, including a $25 million Series A led by Menlo Ventures.
- The tool helps analysts manage a large volume of security alerts, aiming to enhance their decision-making capabilities.
- Crogl's CEO Monzy Merza brings extensive security industry experience from roles at Sandia, Splunk, and HSBC.
- Harmony Intelligence has raised US$3 million in seed funding led by Airtree, with over 30 investors participating.
- The funding responds to the increasing threat of AI-powered cyberattacks.
- More than half of businesses in the US and UK have faced deepfake scams, with 43% being victimized.
- A case involving UK engineering firm Arup resulted in US$25 million losses due to AI deepfake technology impersonating executives.
- Harmony is engaged in cybersecurity testing for advanced AI models and has collaborated with international governments on AI safety initiatives.

title: S Korean chipmakers uncertain as Trump slams CHIPS Act
summary:
- South Korean chipmakers, including Samsung and SK Hynix, face uncertainty after Trump's criticism of the Chips Act.
- The Chips and Science Act had allocated $39 billion to boost domestic semiconductor production.
- Samsung received $6.4 billion and SK Hynix $458 million for their projects in Texas and Indiana.
- Trump described the act as a "tremendous waste of money" and accused South Korea and Taiwan of harming the US chip industry.
- Concerns for Samsung extend beyond potential subsidy revocation as they build their US facility.

title: Mober opens Philippines’ largest EV charging hub
summary:
- Mober has launched the largest commercial EV charging hub in the Philippines, named Central Charge.
- The facility spans 3,000 square meters and includes 56 charging ports, featuring 50 7kW DC chargers and two 60kWh fast chargers.
- Central Charge can support up to 200 EV trucks daily through a three-shift system, reducing vehicle downtime and enhancing logistics for major clients like IKEA and Nestlé.
- Mober, which began transitioning to electric vehicles in 2021, is exploring options to incorporate solar panels and battery energy storage.
- The hub is part of Mober's plan to expand its EV fleet to over 500 units by 2026, reinforcing its commitment to sustainable logistics in the Philippines.

summary:

- Total funding for CaPow reaches $22.5 million.
- Founded in 2019 based on research from Ben-Gurion University, CaPow employs 34 people.
- The flagship technology, Genesis, enables robots to recharge while in motion using radio wave technology.
- Designed for large logistics centers, it aims to reduce downtime and reliance on traditional charging stations.
- The funding will support further development and deployment of the technology in industrial applications.

- Skylark, Japan’s largest table service restaurant chain, uses around 3,000 cat-eared robots for food service.
- Workers like 71-year-old Yasuko Tagawa report significant robotic assistance in their jobs.

title: 3 Simple Ways to Fight Back Against Spam Calls
summary:
- Adding your phone number to the [National Do Not Call Registry](https://www.donotcall.gov/index.html) can significantly reduce spam calls. It takes a month for telemarketers to remove you from their lists after registration.
- Utilizing call-blocking features on smartphones can help manage unwanted calls. Most smartphones allow blocking of individual numbers, effective against repeat offenders.
- Additional options may be needed, as the Do Not Call list is often ineffective against scammers and illegal telemarketers.

sources.title: 3 Simple Ways to Fight Back Against Spam Calls

title: TikTok’s ‘recession brunette’ trend signals tough economic times
summary:
- Many blondes are returning to their natural hair color, which is seen as a reflection of economic struggles.
- TikTok videos showcase users commenting on their hair roots as indicators of financial health.
- Similar trends occurred during the 2007-2009 recession when celebrities embraced darker roots.
- One in six Americans report spending more on beauty than they can afford, leading to reduced salon visits.
- Hairstylist costs are high, making blonde upkeep a luxury, thus promoting the trend of 'recession brunette'.
